docs.title: TrueFidelity User Guide
docs.text: Welcome to the TrueFidelity desktop application documentation. This guide helps you install the app, get productive quickly, and master key workflows like playback analysis, signal visualization, and safe data injection—without exposing internal implementation details.

docs.title: What is TrueFidelity?
docs.text:
TrueFidelity is a desktop application for automotive ECU development, testing, and analysis. It provides a unified platform for:

  • Designing virtual ECU systems with a visual canvas where you can create multi-ECU topologies, configure network connections, and manage system configurations
  • Monitoring running ECU containers in real-time with resource usage tracking, console log aggregation, network traffic analysis, and interactive terminal access
  • Analyzing CAN bus data by playing back log files, decoding signals with DBC definitions, visualizing data in charts, and exporting findings for validation and reporting
  • Injecting test messages safely into controlled environments to validate ECU responses and system behavior

Built on containerized infrastructure, TrueFidelity enables you to develop, test, and debug ECU systems locally using Docker-based virtualized environments. Whether you're designing new systems, monitoring running containers, or analyzing captured CAN traffic, TrueFidelity provides the tools and workflows to streamline your embedded systems development process.

docs.title: Who this guide is for
docs.text:
• Engineers analyzing CAN logs and signals
  • Test and validation teams preparing reports and exports
  • Power users building repeatable workflows and layouts
  • New users who need a safe, step-by-step ramp-up

If you are deploying or administering the app, see your internal runbooks and IT guidance (not covered here).

docs.title: What you can do with TrueFidelity
docs.text:
• Design ECU Systems: Create virtual ECU topologies with drag-and-drop canvas, configure networks, and manage system configurations
  • Monitor Running Systems: Real-time monitoring of ECU containers with resource usage, network traffic, console logs, and terminal access
  • Playback & Analyze CAN Logs: Open and navigate large CAN logs with smooth playback, decode signals with DBC definitions, and visualize data in charts
  • Interactive Terminal Access: Connect to ECU operating systems through integrated terminals for debugging and configuration
  • Build & Deploy: Compile firmware for multiple targets and manage build configurations through visual interfaces
  • Signal Injection: Safely inject test traffic in controlled environments and monitor responses
  • Export & Report: Add annotations and bookmarks, then export findings and reports for validation and documentation

docs.title: Data Injection Overview
docs.text: Data injection lets you transmit CAN frames from TrueFidelity while you monitor playback or live systems. Use it to simulate sensors, reproduce edge cases, or validate control strategies in controlled environments.

docs.title: When to Use Injection
docs.text:
• Simulating missing sensors or altered signals during bench testing
  • Reproducing field issues without waiting for the exact conditions
  • Stress-testing ECUs by increasing message rates
  • Validating firmware updates that rely on specific message sequences

docs.title: Safety First
docs.text:
• Perform injection only in controlled test environments.
  • Keep a quick way to disconnect hardware or stop injection.
  • Document all injected messages to ensure traceability and avoid confusion during analysis.

docs.title: Hardware & Permissions
docs.text:
• Ensure your machine has permissions to access the CAN interface (SocketCAN on Linux, driver packages on Windows).
  • Confirm your hardware supports injection and is not set to monitor-only mode.
  • In multi-user environments, coordinate access to avoid conflicting injections.

docs.title: Panel Overview
docs.text:
Open the Data Injection panel from the sidebar. The panel includes:

  1. Channel selector – Choose the CAN bus (can0, can1, etc.).
  2. Message list – Each entry defines ID, DLC, payload, and flags.
  3. Schedule controls – Configure timing (once, interval, burst, ramp).
  4. Counters – Sent frames, failures, current rate, elapsed time.
  5. Status log – Inline log showing start/stop events and errors.

docs.title: Creating a Message Template
docs.text:
1. Click Add Message.
  2. Enter ID (hex or decimal) and select standard vs. extended.
  3. Set DLC (0–8 for classic CAN).
  4. Enter payload as hex bytes (AA FF 00 01 ...).
  5. Optional: Set flags (RTR, BRS) depending on your build.

docs.title: Scheduling Injection
docs.text:
• Once: Sends the message once after a specified delay.
  • Interval: Repeats at a fixed rate (e.g., every 100 ms).
  • Burst: Sends N frames rapidly, then pauses for M seconds.
  • Ramp: Gradually increases or decreases the rate across a defined duration.
  • Custom script: Some deployments allow importing a script for complex patterns.

Configure the schedule in the lower portion of the panel; preview charts show expected timing.

docs.title: Starting & Monitoring Injection
docs.text:
1. Review hardware connection and message templates.
  2. Click Start. The status indicator turns green.
  3. Monitor counters to confirm messages are being sent.
  4. Watch the Messages panel to verify the injected frames appear as expected.
  5. Click Stop to end injection immediately.

Warning

If you see transmission errors or failures incrementing rapidly, stop injection and inspect hardware or bus load.

docs.title: Profiles
docs.text:
• Use Save Profile to store a set of messages and schedules as a .tfinject file.
  • Load profiles to reproduce scenarios quickly (e.g., ABS_failover, Sensor_spike_test).
  • Profiles capture message templates, schedules, and channel selection.

docs.title: Integration with Playback
docs.text:
• Run injection while playing back logs to blend simulated messages with recorded data.
  • Use different channels to separate injected frames from recorded ones if needed.
  • Annotate injection start/stop times to maintain traceability.

docs.title: Logs & Audit Trail
docs.text:
• The injection panel logs start/stop events, errors, and parameter changes.
  • Export injection logs from the panel or Help → Show Logs for audits.
  • Include injection profiles and logs in project archives.

docs.title: Troubleshooting Injection
docs.text: Issue Solution Messages not appearing Verify the correct channel is selected and not in listen-only mode. Check for bus-off conditions. Injection stops unexpectedly Look for hardware errors in the status log; ensure other tools are not controlling the interface. Rate inaccurate Adjust schedule settings; confirm the system clock is stable and the machine is not under heavy CPU load. Unable to start Confirm activation license includes injection features and the profile is valid.

  • Combine injection tests with Annotations & Bookmarks to document outcomes.

docs.title: Safety & Best Practices
docs.text: Data injection can influence real systems. Use this checklist to run tests safely, protect equipment, and maintain clear documentation.

docs.title: General Safety Rules
docs.text:
1. Test Environment Only – Perform injection on bench setups or controlled environments unless explicitly approved for vehicle testing.
  2. Physical Safeguards – Ensure an emergency stop, power cut, or hardware disconnect is within reach.
  3. Document Intent – Record why you are injecting, which messages, and expected results before starting.
  4. Team Communication – Notify everyone connected to the bus that injection is active.
  5. Monitor Continuously – Watch the status indicators and message counters to catch unexpected behavior.

docs.title: Pre-Test Checklist
docs.text:
• Verify activation and user permissions allow injection.
  • Confirm hardware connections (interface cables, termination resistors) are secure.
  • Backup original logs and profile configurations.
  • Load the appropriate injection profile and review message templates.
  • Ensure the system under test is ready (ECUs powered, simulation running).

docs.title: During Injection
docs.text:
• Start with low frequencies; ramp up only after confirming stability.
  • Observe the system response in real time via Messages and Charts.
  • Keep annotations of notable responses or anomalies with timestamps.
  • If errors or warnings appear in the injection log, stop immediately.

docs.title: Post-Test Actions
docs.text:
• Stop injection and confirm the status indicator returns to idle.
  • Save project changes, including annotations and profile adjustments.
  • Export injection logs and include them in your project documentation.
  • Reset the system under test to a known safe state.

docs.title: Handling Failures
docs.text: Scenario Response Hardware enters bus-off Stop injection, reset the CAN interface, and verify bus load. System under test behaves unexpectedly Stop injection, document behavior, and analyze logs before repeating. Application crashes Gather logs from Help → Show Logs and report to support. Injection schedule misfires Review profile settings; run a dry simulation without hardware to validate timing.

docs.title: Compliance & Traceability
docs.text:
• Assign a unique test ID to each injection session.
  • Store profiles, logs, annotations, and exports together.
  • Keep a changelog of profile revisions (date, author, purpose).
  • Follow your organization’s safety review process before running high-risk injections.

docs.title: Team Practices
docs.text:
• Use shared templates for annotations and reports to maintain consistency.
  • Conduct regular reviews of injection profiles to retire outdated scenarios.
  • Pair new engineers with experienced operators before granting independent injection access.

docs.title: Automation Safeguards
docs.text:
• When running automated scripts, include timeouts and fail-safe checks.
  • Log every automated injection run with timestamps and outcome.
  • Schedule automated runs outside of active working hours unless supervised.

docs.title: Legal & Ethical Considerations
docs.text:
• Do not deploy injection against live production vehicles or customer equipment without explicit authorization.
  • Follow regional regulations regarding CAN manipulation and data privacy.
  • Ensure encryption keys or security tokens remain protected if your platform uses encrypted channels.

  • Release Channels – Stay updated with patches that may affect injection safety.
  • Tutorial: Injection Scenario Walkthrough – Step-by-step example combining these best practices.

docs.title: Schedules & Profiles
docs.text: Schedules define when and how injection messages are sent. Profiles bundle schedules and messages so you can reuse scenarios. This guide dives into each schedule type and offers practical examples.

docs.title: Once
docs.text:
• Sends a message a single time after an optional delay.
  • Useful for triggering events or sending diagnostic requests.
  • Configure delay in seconds or milliseconds.

docs.title: Interval
docs.text:
• Repeats a message at a fixed rate (e.g., every 100 ms).
  • Supports fractional intervals (0.1 s) and frequency notation (10 Hz).
  • Optionally align to playback time by enabling Sync with timeline.

docs.title: Burst
docs.text:
• Sends a burst of N frames quickly (burst size) followed by a pause (cooldown).
  • Repeat bursts until stopped or after a defined duration.
  • Example: 50 frames burst, 5-second pause, repeat 10 times.

docs.title: Ramp
docs.text:
• Gradually changes the interval between frames.
  • Specify start rate, end rate, duration, and ramp shape (linear, exponential).
  • Great for stress testing controllers by ramping from 2 Hz to 50 Hz.

docs.title: Custom
docs.text:
• Import custom schedule scripts (if your edition supports it) using JSON or Python-based instructions.
  • Scripts allow conditional logic, randomization, and complex scenarios.

docs.title: Setting Up Schedules
docs.text:
1. Select a message template in the injection panel.
  2. Choose the schedule type from the dropdown.
  3. Configure parameters (delay, rate, duration, repeat count).
  4. Preview the timeline graph to validate timing.
  5. Save your settings before starting injection.

Tip

Combine multiple messages with different schedules in the same profile to simulate realistic bus activity (e.g., heartbeat + sporadic fault message).

docs.title: Profiles
docs.text:
Profiles collect messages and schedules into reusable packages.

  • Create profile: Configure messages and schedules, then click Save Profile.
  • Load profile: Click Load Profile, select a .tfinject file, and review the summary before starting.
  • Export profile: Share with teammates to reproduce tests.
  • Versioning: Include version numbers or dates in profile names (e.g., ABS_failover_v3.tfinject).

Profiles store: - Channel selection - Message templates (ID, DLC, payload) - Schedule settings - Default duration and stop conditions

docs.title: Heartbeat Simulation
docs.text:
• Message ID: 0x120
  • Payload: 01 7F 00 00 00 00 00 00
  • Schedule: Interval 100 ms
  • Use case: Simulate a sensor heartbeat during bench testing.

docs.title: Fault Injection Burst
docs.text:
• Message ID: 0x3E0
  • Payload: FF FF FF FF 00 00 00 00
  • Schedule: Burst (burst size 30, cooldown 3 s, repeat 5 times)
  • Use case: Stress ECU error handling routine.

docs.title: Ramp Stress Test
docs.text:
• Message ID: 0x245
  • Payload: AA 00 AA 00 55 55 00 01
  • Schedule: Ramp from 5 Hz to 50 Hz over 60 seconds, hold for 30 seconds, ramp down.
  • Use case: Validate firmware response to increasing data rates.

docs.title: Managing Profiles
docs.text:
• Store profiles in a dedicated folder within the project (e.g., profiles/).
  • Document the purpose, message IDs, and expected outcomes in a README.
  • Use version control to track profile changes alongside firmware builds.

docs.title: Monitoring During Scheduled Injection
docs.text:
• Watch the counters (sent, failed, rate) to ensure the schedule runs as expected.
  • Use annotations to mark the start and end of injection runs.
  • Verify actual timing using the Messages panel by filtering for injected IDs and checking timestamp spacing.

docs.title: Troubleshooting Schedules
docs.text: Issue Resolution Interval drift Check system load; high CPU usage can delay timers. Reduce other workload or use a dedicated machine. Burst stops early Ensure the repeat count is set correctly and there are no hardware errors. Ramp doesn't reach target rate Confirm the duration is long enough and the channel is not saturating. Profile fails to load The file may reference a channel or message format not available in this environment. Edit the profile or update hardware configuration.

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
• Test schedules with playback paused before mixing with live data.
  • Label injection profiles with project IDs and expected outcomes.
  • Keep profiles under version control with change logs.
  • Use separate profiles for destructive and non-destructive tests; never run destructive profiles on live systems without authorization.

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Review Safety & Best Practices for operational guidance.
  • Combine schedules with annotations by following the Injection Scenario Walkthrough tutorial.
  • Export injection logs and profiles to include in validation reports.

docs.title: Concepts & Terminology
docs.text: This glossary clarifies the key terms TrueFidelity users encounter when navigating projects, decoding signals, and injecting data. Understanding these concepts up front reduces onboarding friction and ensures consistent communication across teams.

docs.title: System Design
docs.text:
• System – A configuration defining multiple ECUs, their connections, network topologies, and build settings. Systems are saved as .tfsystem files.
  • ECU (Electronic Control Unit) – A virtual ECU instance running in a Docker container. Each ECU has a name, binary, network interfaces, and runtime configuration.
  • System Canvas – The visual workspace for designing ECU topologies by dragging and connecting components.
  • Network Edge – A connection between ECUs representing a CAN bus, Ethernet link, or other network interface.
  • Toolbox – A panel containing reusable ECU types, network components, and gateway elements that can be dragged onto the canvas.

docs.title: Projects & Files
docs.text:
• Project – A container that remembers open files, panel layouts, watch lists, annotations, and definitions. Projects are saved as .tfproj files referencing data stored elsewhere.
  • Workspace/Layout – The arrangement of panels in the main window (timeline, charts, messages, monitoring panels). Layouts can be saved within a project and reused.
  • Panel – Any dockable UI component such as System Canvas, ECU Status, Console, Messages, Charts, Signals, Annotations, or Data Injection. Panels can be docked, floated, or collapsed.

docs.title: CAN Log Analysis
docs.text:
• Timeline – The visual bar representing elapsed time in the loaded CAN log(s). The playhead moves along it, and users can select ranges for export or looping.
  • Channel/Bus – A logical CAN interface (e.g., can0, can1). When injecting or filtering data, you select which channel to use.
  • Segment/Range – A highlighted portion of the timeline defined by dragging or specifying start/end times. Segments drive exports, looped playback, filtering, and reporting.

docs.title: Data Terminology
docs.text:
• CAN Frame – A single message on the CAN bus, defined by ID, DLC, payload, timestamp, and optional flags (extended ID, RTR).
  • Signal – A decoded value derived from a CAN payload using a definition file (usually DBC). Signals have units, scaling, and offsets.
  • Message Definition – Metadata that explains how to decode a CAN frame into one or more signals. Stored in DBC or other definition formats.
  • Event Marker – A bookmark or annotation added at a specific time to capture context, issues, or observations.
  • Counters/Statistics – Real-time metrics displayed during playback (messages per second, dropped frames, current time).

docs.title: File Types
docs.text:
• Log File – Recorded CAN traffic. Common formats: MDF4 (.mf4, .mdf), BLF (.blf), ASC (.asc), CSV.
  • Definition File – DBC (.dbc), ARXML, or other mapping files that define signals and scaling for raw frames.
  • Export File – Data generated from TrueFidelity (CSV segments, charts as images, annotation reports, injection profiles).
  • Profile – Serialized configuration for injection schedules or saved filters (depending on feature).

docs.title: Playback Concepts
docs.text:
• Playback Speed – The rate at which the timeline advances relative to recorded time (0.25× to 8×).
  • Loop Mode – Repeats the selected range on the timeline until disabled. Useful for investigating short events.
  • Cursors – Vertical markers in Charts used to measure time difference between two points.
  • Auto-Scale – Chart mode that adjusts Y-axis bounds automatically based on visible data. Disable to compare runs with consistent scaling.
  • Filter-to-Range – Restricts visible data (Messages, Charts) to the currently selected timeline range.

docs.title: Injection Concepts
docs.text:
• Injection Panel – Panel used to schedule CAN frames for transmission alongside playback or live monitoring.
  • Message Template – Defines ID, DLC, payload, and optional flags for a single injected message.
  • Schedule – Timing definition for an injection (once, interval, burst, ramp).
  • Profile – Grouping of templates and schedules saved for reuse. Profiles can be exported/imported for collaboration.
  • Safety Guard – A mechanism that warns or blocks injection when certain risk conditions are met (e.g., missing hardware acknowledgement).

docs.title: Project Collaboration Terms
docs.text:
• Pinned Signal – A signal flagged in the Signals panel to keep it readily available across sessions.
  • Watch List – A curated list of pinned signals displayed in the sidebar for quick charting.
  • Annotation Tag – A keyword applied to annotations (e.g., safety, powertrain, regression). Tags help filter notes and build thematic reports.
  • Shared Layout – A project layout exported and imported by teammates to synchronize workspace arrangement.
  • Session Log – Auto-generated background logs capturing errors, warnings, and telemetry (if enabled). Access via Help → Show Logs.

docs.title: Monitoring & Runtime Terminology
docs.text:
• ECU Status – Current state of an ECU container (Running, Stopped, Starting, Error). Displayed in ECU Status panel with color-coded indicators.
  • Container – Docker container instance running an ECU binary. Each ECU in a system runs as a separate container.
  • Console Logs – Aggregated standard output and error streams from all ECU containers. Viewable in the Console panel with filtering.
  • Resource Metrics – CPU and memory usage data collected from running ECU containers. Displayed as real-time graphs in Resource Monitor panel.
  • Terminal Access – Interactive shell access to ECU operating systems through the Terminal panel. Provides command-line debugging and configuration.
  • Network Traffic – CAN messages flowing between ECUs. Captured and displayed in real-time in the Network Traffic panel.
  • Process Monitor – View of running processes within ECU containers, including CPU/memory per process.

docs.title: Status Indicators
docs.text:
• Activation Badge – An icon in the status bar showing license status (green for activated, amber for trial, red for expired).
  • ECU Status Indicators – Color-coded states in ECU Status panel: green (running), yellow (starting), red (error), gray (stopped).
  • Terminal Connection Status – Indicators in Terminal panel: green (connected), yellow (connecting), red (connection failed).
  • Autosave Indicator – Flashes when the project autosaves; disable or adjust frequency in Settings → General.
  • Hardware Status – For systems with CAN hardware integration, device state is shown in the footer (connected, disconnected, error).

docs.title: Keyboard Shortcut Vocabulary
docs.text:
• Toggle Panels – Use Ctrl/Cmd + number (e.g., 1 for Signals, 2 for Messages) to show or hide panels quickly.
  • Command Palette – Press Ctrl/Cmd + P to bring up a search-driven command list (if enabled in your build).
  • Cursors – Add with Shift + C (configurable) to mark points on charts.

docs.title: Reporting & Exports
docs.text:
• Report Builder – A guided wizard that combines annotations, screenshots, and summary metrics into PDF/HTML outputs.
  • Batch Export Queue – A task list that processes multiple timeline segments or files overnight.
  • Snapshot – A quick capture of the current chart or panel state saved as an image.

docs.title: Troubleshooting Vocabulary
docs.text:
• Safe Mode – Launch flag that disables hardware acceleration (--safe-mode). Use for diagnosing display issues.
  • Verbose Logging – Start TrueFidelity with --verbose to capture additional diagnostics in log files.
  • Compatibility Mode – A playback option that relaxes parsing strictness for older log formats; configure under Settings → Data.

  • Encourage consistent terminology when filing support tickets to speed up triage.

docs.title: First Launch & Activation
docs.text: Use this guide immediately after installing TrueFidelity to complete activation, set defaults, and verify your environment. All steps are user-facing and omit internal implementation details.

docs.title: Launching the App for the First Time
docs.text:
1. Start TrueFidelity from your platform’s application menu.
  2. A splash screen appears for a few seconds; then the main window opens with the default layout.
  3. If the splash screen hangs for longer than 30 seconds, see the troubleshooting section below.

docs.title: License Agreement
docs.text:
• Review the license agreement presented on first launch.
  • Click I agree to continue. If you do not agree, close the application—no changes are written.
  • For an enterprise distribution, ensure legal teams capture the agreement text outside the application for auditing.

docs.title: Activation Options
docs.text: TrueFidelity can operate with online or offline activation depending on your deployment.

docs.title: Online Activation
docs.text:
1. Locate your license key (usually delivered via email or portal).
  2. Paste the key into the activation prompt.
  1. If your network requires a proxy, click Proxy Settings, provide the host/port, and credentials if needed.
  1. Click Activate. Online activation completes within seconds.
  2. The license status indicator in the lower-right corner turns green when successful.

docs.title: Offline Activation
docs.text:
1. On a connected machine, generate an offline license file from your distribution portal.
  2. Transfer the file to the air-gapped workstation.
  3. Choose Offline activation and select the license file.
  4. Confirm the activation summary shows your organization name and expiration (if any).

License grace period

If you accidentally close the activation window, TrueFidelity allows a short trial period before requiring activation. A banner will remind you until activation is complete.

docs.title: Initial Setup Wizard
docs.text:
After activation you will see a short wizard to set preferred defaults. These choices can be changed later under Settings.

  1. Default project folder: Select a location on fast storage (SSD). All new projects use this path unless you override it.

  1. Default log folder: Choose where incoming CAN logs are usually stored.

  1. Default export folder: Define a destination for exported segments, reports, and annotations.

  1. Telemetry preference: Opt in or out of anonymous usage metrics (if offered in your distribution).

  1. Automatic updates: Keep enabled for most environments; disable if you operate under release control.

docs.title: Verifying Hardware and Permissions
docs.text:
• Open Help → About to confirm version number and license details.
  • Create a test project (File → New Project), save it in your project folder, then close and reopen the project to ensure read/write access.
  • Open Settings → General and verify the UI language, theme, and time display preferences.
  • Navigate to Settings → Playback to confirm default playback speed, looping behavior, and cursor display options.
  • If you plan to inject data, ensure the user has necessary OS-level permissions for network interfaces.

docs.title: Default Layout Walkthrough
docs.text: The default workspace adapts based on your workflow mode:

docs.title: System Design Mode (when creating new systems)
docs.text:
• System Canvas – Visual editor for placing ECUs and configuring networks
  • Toolbox – Component library for adding ECUs and network elements
  • Properties Panel – Configuration for selected ECU or network
  • Project Explorer – File tree for system files and assets

docs.title: Monitoring Mode (when systems are running)
docs.text:
• ECU Status – Overview of running ECU containers
  • Console – Aggregated logs from all ECUs
  • Resource Monitor – Real-time CPU and memory graphs
  • Network Traffic – CAN message monitoring

docs.title: CAN Log Analysis Mode (when analyzing log files)
docs.text:
• Timeline – Playback timeline with playhead and selection
  • Messages – Raw CAN frames in timestamp order
  • Charts – Signal visualization and plotting
  • Signals – Browse decoded signals from DBC files

Take a moment to expand and collapse panels, open the context menus, and familiarize yourself with the UI. The UI Tour page provides screenshots and descriptions of each region.

docs.title: Option A: CAN Log Analysis Test
docs.text:
1. Open a sample log: Use File → Open to select a known-good CAN log file.
  2. Play: Press the space bar or click the play button. Confirm the timeline moves and message counters update.
  3. Seek: Click at different points on the timeline and watch the data in Messages and Charts change.
  4. Add a signal: Open the Signals panel, search for a familiar signal, and pin it to the watch list.
  5. Plot: Add the signal to Charts to confirm decoding is working.
  6. Export test segment: Drag-select five seconds on the timeline, then export to CSV and verify the file is written to your export folder.
  7. Close project: Ensure there are no errors when closing the application; reopen it to confirm your preferences persist.

docs.title: Option B: System Design Test
docs.text:
1. Create a new system: Use File → New to create a test system.
  2. Add an ECU: Drag an ECU from the Toolbox onto the System Canvas.
  3. Configure properties: Select the ECU and verify the Properties panel shows editable fields.
  4. Save system: Press Ctrl/Cmd + S and confirm the system file is created.
  5. Start ECU (if Docker available): Right-click the ECU and select Start to verify container launch.
  6. View monitoring: Open ECU Status and Console panels to see runtime data.
  7. Close system: Ensure no errors when closing; reopen to verify persistence.

Note

The System Design workflow requires Docker Desktop to be running for ECU containers to start. CAN Log Analysis works independently of Docker.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: This guide walks through installing the TrueFidelity desktop application on Windows, macOS, and Linux. It also covers system requirements, preparatory steps, updates, uninstallation, and troubleshooting. Share this page with end users; it contains no internal implementation details.

docs.title: System Requirements
docs.text:
• Operating systems: Windows 10/11 (x64), macOS 12+ (Intel or Apple Silicon), Linux (x86_64) with modern desktop environment
  • CPU: Quad-core 2.5 GHz or better (8+ cores recommended for large logs)
  • Memory: Minimum 8 GB; 16 GB or more for long sessions and simultaneous exports
  • Storage: 1 GB free for the app plus capacity for log archives and exports (SSD strongly recommended)
  • Graphics: GPU with updated drivers for hardware acceleration (integrated GPUs are supported)
  • Permissions: Ability to install desktop applications and read/write to your log and export folders

docs.title: Downloading the Installer
docs.text:
1. Visit your official distribution portal or shared release storage.
  2. Choose the installer for your platform:
  3. Windows: .exe
  4. macOS: .dmg
  5. Linux: .AppImage, .deb, or .rpm
  6. Verify the filename and checksum (if provided). For the highest assurance, compare the SHA-256 checksum published with the release.
  7. Place the installer on a local disk before running (avoid network shares for initial installation).

Keep past installers

If you operate in a validated environment, archive the installers you have approved. This lets you revert quickly if a new release requires certification.

docs.title: Windows Installation
docs.text:
1. Right-click the installer and select Run as administrator (optional but helps when installing for all users).
  2. If Windows SmartScreen prompts you, choose More info → Run anyway (verify the publisher matches your organization).
  1. Follow the setup wizard:
  2. Scope: install for Just me or All users.
  3. Destination folder: the default C:\Program Files\TrueFidelity works for most deployments.
  4. Shortcuts: enable Start menu and desktop entries for quick access.
  1. Click Install and wait for completion.
  1. Launch TrueFidelity from the Start menu to verify a successful install.

docs.title: Windows Troubleshooting
docs.text:
• SmartScreen block persists: Ensure you downloaded from a trusted source or contact IT to add the certificate to your allow list.
  • App does not launch: Check antivirus quarantine logs and add the installation folder to your safe-list if necessary.
  • Silent install: Use TrueFidelity-x.y.z.exe /S /allusers to script deployment.

docs.title: macOS Installation
docs.text:
1. Double-click the downloaded .dmg file to mount it.
  1. Drag the TrueFidelity application into the Applications folder shortcut.
  2. Eject the disk image.
  1. Launch the app from Launchpad or Spotlight.
  1. If macOS warns the app is from an unidentified developer, right-click the app, choose Open, then click Open again. Alternatively, go to System Settings → Privacy & Security and allow the app.

docs.title: macOS Troubleshooting
docs.text:
• App immediately closes: Remove any quarantine attributes using xattr -rd com.apple.quarantine /Applications/TrueFidelity.app.
  • Rosetta prompt: Apple Silicon systems may request Rosetta if Intel binaries are used; allow installation when prompted.

docs.title: AppImage
docs.text:
1. Mark the file executable: chmod +x TrueFidelity-x.y.z.AppImage.
  2. Run the AppImage: ./TrueFidelity-x.y.z.AppImage.
  3. Accept integration prompts if you want menu entries.

docs.title: Debian/Ubuntu (.deb)
docs.text: sudo apt install ./truefidelity_x.y.z_amd64.deb

docs.title: RHEL/Fedora (.rpm)
docs.text: sudo dnf install ./truefidelity-x.y.z.x86_64.rpm

docs.title: Linux Troubleshooting
docs.text:
• Missing libraries: Use your package manager to install libfuse, gtk3, or other prerequisites indicated in the terminal.
  • Wayland issues: If the UI does not render, try launching with --disable-gpu or from an X11 session.

docs.title: First Launch Checklist
docs.text:
• Confirm the splash screen appears and transitions to the main window within 30 seconds.
  • Approve any firewall prompts to allow local networking features (used for internal services).
  • Verify you can open the Help → About dialog to check version and license status.
  • Create a test project in a temporary folder and delete it afterwards to ensure write permissions.

docs.title: Updating TrueFidelity
docs.text:
• Automatic check: If enabled, the app will notify you about updates. Follow prompts to download the newest installer.
  • Manual update: Download the latest installer and run it over the existing installation. Your settings, activation, and projects remain intact.
  • Version pinning: When you must stay on a particular version, disable auto-updates in Settings → Updates and retain the approved installer.

Reboot after major upgrades

If the upgrade includes driver-level components, reboot to ensure hardware integrations reload correctly.

docs.title: Uninstalling
docs.text:
• Windows: Settings → Apps → Installed apps → TrueFidelity → Uninstall. Optional: remove leftover data in %APPDATA%\TrueFidelity.
  • macOS: Drag the app from Applications to the Trash. Delete support files in ~/Library/Application Support/TrueFidelity if you want a clean slate.
  • Linux (package): sudo apt remove truefidelity or sudo dnf remove truefidelity.
  • Linux (AppImage): Delete the file plus any desktop integration entries created under ~/.local/share.

docs.title: Quick Start (5 Minutes)
docs.text: Use this hands-on walkthrough to experience a complete TrueFidelity workflow in about five minutes. It assumes you have already installed the app and completed first-boot activation.

docs.title: Scenario Overview
docs.text:
Goal: Load a CAN log, analyze a signal, annotate an event, inject a brief message, and export a segment for review.

Time estimate: 5–7 minutes.

Prerequisites: - A sample CAN log file (MDF4/BLF/ASC) - Optional DBC file for decoding - Activation completed and default folders defined

docs.title: Step 1 – Create a Project
docs.text:
1. Launch TrueFidelity.
  2. Go to File → New Project.
  1. Name the project QS-demo and select your project folder.
  1. Click Create. The project appears in the left sidebar.

Tip

Projects remember which files, layouts, filters, and panels you are using. Create dedicated projects for recurring test cases.

docs.title: Step 2 – Import a Log File
docs.text:
1. Choose File → Open.
  2. Select your sample log file.
  3. Confirm it appears under Files in the project explorer.
  4. The timeline auto-populates with duration and counters.

Optional: If you have a DBC file, choose Project → Import Definitions and load it now for signal decoding.

docs.title: Step 3 – Play and Explore
docs.text:
1. Press Space (or click the play button) to start playback.
  1. Adjust speed using the playback speed dropdown (1×, 2×, 0.5×).
  1. Use the mouse wheel over the timeline to zoom into detail.
  2. Click a specific timestamp to jump the playhead and observe the Messages panel update.

docs.title: Step 4 – Pin and Plot Signals
docs.text:
1. Open the Signals panel (Ctrl/Cmd + 1 if you prefer shortcuts).
  2. Search for a signal (for example vehicle_speed).
  3. Click the pin icon to add it to the watch list.
  4. Open the Charts panel; drag the pinned signal into the chart.
  5. Watch real-time trends as playback continues.

Note

Multiple signals can be overlaid on a single chart. Adjust axes or enable auto-scale if ranges differ significantly.

docs.title: Step 5 – Annotate an Event
docs.text:
1. Pause playback at an interesting moment.
  2. Press A or click the Add Annotation button.
  3. Enter a title (e.g., “Speed spike”) and optional description.
  4. Add tags such as validation, spike, or investigate.
  5. Save the annotation; it becomes part of the project and can be exported later.

docs.title: Step 6 – Optional Injection Burst
docs.text:
1. Open the Data Injection panel from the sidebar.
  2. Choose the active channel (e.g., can0).
  3. Add a message ID, DLC, and payload (for example 0x321, DLC 8, payload DE AD BE EF 00 00 00 01).
  4. Set a schedule to Once with a 0 second delay.
  5. Click Start to inject; observe the Messages panel to confirm the frame appears.
  6. Click Stop to prevent further injections.

docs.title: Step 7 – Select a Range for Export
docs.text:
1. Drag the timeline to highlight 20 seconds that include your annotation.
  2. Click Loop (optional) to play the range repeatedly for verification.
  3. Ensure the annotation marker lies within the selected range.

docs.title: Step 8 – Export the Segment
docs.text:
1. Go to File → Export Segment.
  2. Choose CSV or MDF4 depending on downstream tools.
  3. Enter a descriptive filename such as qs-demo_speed-spike.csv.
  4. Confirm the destination folder matches your export defaults.
  5. Click Export. A toast notification confirms success; the file opens in your file explorer if OS integration permits.

docs.title: Step 9 – Review Deliverables
docs.text:
• Open the exported file in your preferred viewer to confirm data looks correct.
  • Navigate to Annotations panel and verify your note is listed.
  • Use Help → Show Logs to familiarize yourself with diagnostic file locations.

docs.title: Cleanup (Optional)
docs.text:
• Delete the sample project via the project explorer context menu if you want a clean slate.
  • Otherwise, keep it to use as a baseline for future quick demonstrations.

docs.title: Privacy & Data Handling
docs.text: Handle logs, exports, and reports responsibly to protect proprietary and personal data.

docs.title: Data Classification
docs.text:
• Confidential: Proprietary vehicle data, calibration values, unreleased feature information. Store in secure repositories with access controls.
  • Restricted: Logs containing VINs, driver identifiers, or other personal data. Follow regional privacy laws (GDPR, CCPA).
  • Public: Sanitized datasets approved for open sharing. Confirm with management before classifying data as public.

docs.title: Storage & Access
docs.text:
• Use encrypted drives or secure servers for confidential logs.
  • Limit access to authorized team members. Use group permissions rather than individual sharing where possible.
  • Archive completed projects to long-term storage with retention policies (e.g., 3–5 years or as mandated).

docs.title: Anonymization & Redaction
docs.text:
• Remove or mask personal data (names, addresses, VINs) from logs before sharing externally.
  • Replace unique identifiers with pseudonyms when evaluating performance across multiple units.
  • Document transformation steps so recipients understand what was changed.

docs.title: Sharing Guidelines
docs.text:
• Share projects via secure channels (VPN, encrypted file transfer, company-approved cloud storage).
  • Never email large logs or exports without encryption.
  • Include classification labels in filenames or accompanying README files.
  • Keep a distribution list showing who received which dataset.

docs.title: Logs & Exports in Reports
docs.text:
• Reports often include screenshots or data extracts. Ensure sensitive fields are blurred or removed.
  • Highlight any remaining confidential data so reviewers handle it appropriately.
  • When sending to external partners, follow contractual data-sharing agreements.

docs.title: Injection Profiles & Scripts
docs.text:
• Injection profiles may reveal proprietary message definitions. Treat them as confidential.
  • Store profiles with the same access controls as the matching project.
  • Remove sensitive payload values before sharing with third parties unless authorized.

docs.title: Telemetry & Analytics
docs.text:
• If TrueFidelity collects anonymous telemetry, ensure opt-in aligns with company policy.
  • Review telemetry to confirm no personal or proprietary information is transmitted inadvertently.

docs.title: Device Hygiene
docs.text:
• Lock workstations when unattended.
  • Avoid storing confidential data on personal devices unless explicitly allowed.
  • Use company-approved antivirus and patch management tools to reduce leak risk.

docs.title: Incident Response
docs.text:
1. Immediately report suspected data leaks to your security team.
  2. Provide details: what data, when, who had access.
  3. Follow company incident response procedures to contain and remediate.

docs.title: Legal & Compliance
docs.text:
• Consult legal counsel for regulations relevant to your region (GDPR, CCPA, ISO 21434).
  • Maintain audit logs of who accessed or modified critical datasets.
  • Adhere to customer NDAs and project-specific confidentiality agreements.

docs.title: Best Practices Checklist
docs.text:
• [ ] Classify data before storing or sharing.
  • [ ] Use secure storage with proper permissions.
  • [ ] Anonymize personal identifiers.
  • [ ] Encrypt transfers and archives.
  • [ ] Document who received exports.
  • [ ] Review reports for sensitive content before release.

docs.title: Version Numbering
docs.text: TrueFidelity uses semantic versioning: MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH. - MAJOR – Significant changes; may include breaking updates or new hardware support. - MINOR – Feature additions and improvements. - PATCH – Bug fixes and small enhancements.

docs.title: Update Process
docs.text:
1. Review release notes for highlights, breaking changes, and upgrade instructions.
  2. Back up critical projects and settings (Settings → Backup).
  3. Download the installer from your authorized portal.
  4. Run the installer; existing settings and projects remain intact.
  5. Restart TrueFidelity and verify the version under Help → About.

Tip

Schedule upgrades during low-activity periods. For shared labs, coordinate with the team and document the change in your tool calendar.

docs.title: Rollback Strategy
docs.text:
• Keep previous installers archived (e.g., in your software repository).
  • If issues arise post-upgrade, uninstall the current version and reinstall the prior stable build.
  • Restore backed-up settings if necessary.

docs.title: Testing & Validation
docs.text:
• For regulated environments, run smoke tests on staging machines before rolling out widely.
  • Use representative projects and logs to ensure compatibility.
  • Document test results and approval before updating production systems.

docs.title: Automatic Update Checks
docs.text:
• Enable or disable under Settings → Updates.
  • Automatic checks notify you of new builds but do not install automatically unless configured.
  • Beta/nightly channels may require manual opt-in.

docs.title: Communication
docs.text:

  • Notify stakeholders (test teams, developers, support staff) about planned upgrades.
  • Provide rollback instructions in case of unexpected behavior.

Q: How do we access beta/nightly builds? A: Contact your license administrator or vendor representative to enable additional channels.

Q: Are settings compatible across versions? A: Minor and patch releases remain compatible. Review release notes for any major-version migration steps.

docs.title: Frequently Asked Questions
docs.text: Find answers to common user questions about TrueFidelity.

docs.title: General
docs.text:
Q: Which operating systems are supported? A: Windows 10/11 (x64), macOS 12+, and Linux (x86_64). Use the latest patches for best results.

Q: Does TrueFidelity require administrative privileges? A: Installation may require elevated permissions; day-to-day usage does not unless you access protected CAN interfaces.

Q: Where are configuration files stored? A: Typically under the user profile: %APPDATA%\TrueFidelity (Windows), ~/Library/Application Support/TrueFidelity (macOS), ~/.config/truefidelity (Linux).

docs.title: Projects & Files
docs.text:
Q: How do I share a project with colleagues? A: Zip the .tfproj file along with referenced logs, definitions, screenshots, and exports. Use relative paths to keep links intact.

Q: Can I open multiple projects at once? A: TrueFidelity opens one project per window. You can run multiple instances if your system resources allow it.

Q: How do I recover a project after a crash? A: Reopen TrueFidelity; autosave restores the last checkpoint. If autosave was disabled, manually load the most recent .tfproj backup.

docs.title: Playback
docs.text:
Q: Why does playback stutter on large logs? A: Ensure logs reside on an SSD, close unused panels, and reduce chart complexity. See Performance Tips for more suggestions.

Q: Can I sync playback across multiple machines? A: Not directly. Export segments or share projects so teammates can run the same playback on their machines.

docs.title: Signals & Definitions
docs.text:
Q: What happens if multiple DBC files define the same signal? A: TrueFidelity uses the highest-priority definition. Reorder or disable definitions in the sidebar to select the correct one.

Q: How do I handle encrypted payloads? A: Decrypt them using your organization’s tooling before importing; TrueFidelity doesn’t perform decryption.

docs.title: Data Injection
docs.text:
Q: Is injection available in all editions? A: Injection requires a license tier that enables it. Check your activation status or contact your admin.

Q: Can I run injection and playback simultaneously? A: Yes. Use separate channels or annotate injected frames to keep them organized.

Q: How do I stop injection quickly? A: Click Stop in the injection panel or use the emergency hardware cutoff on your test bench.

docs.title: Exports & Reports
docs.text:
Q: Why is my export empty? A: Ensure the selected timeline range contains data and filters aren’t excluding everything.

Q: Can I customize report templates? A: Yes. Clone a template in the Report Builder and adjust branding, sections, and default text.

Q: Where are exports saved? A: By default, in the export folder set under Settings → Exports. The status bar displays the path after each export.

docs.title: Performance & Stability
docs.text:
Q: How do I speed up large exports? A: Use binary formats (MDF4), run exports from fast storage, and queue them during off-hours.

Q: The app feels sluggish after hours of use. A: Restart TrueFidelity to release cached resources and review Performance Tips for proactive tuning.

docs.title: Support
docs.text:
Q: How do I capture logs for support? A: Use Help → Show Logs, compress the folder, and include it with your support request.

Q: What information should I provide to support? A: Include OS version, app version, reproduction steps, logs, project or sample logs (if possible), and relevant screenshots.

docs.title: Updates & Licensing
docs.text:
Q: How do I update TrueFidelity? A: Download the latest installer from your distribution portal and run it. Your settings and projects remain intact.

Q: Will updates modify my project files? A: Projects are forward compatible; however, always keep backups before upgrading.

Q: How can I transfer a license to a new machine? A: Deactivate on the old machine (Help → License) and activate on the new one using your license credentials.

docs.title: System Design & ECU Management
docs.text:
Q: How do I add an ECU to my system? A: Drag an ECU component from the Toolbox onto the System Canvas. Then configure its properties (binary path, network interfaces) in the Properties panel.

Q: Can I run multiple ECU systems simultaneously? A: Yes, but resource usage scales with the number of ECUs. Each ECU container consumes CPU and memory. Monitor resources using the Resource Monitor panel.

Q: How do I connect ECUs on different networks? A: Use a Gateway ECU component in the Toolbox. Connect it to ECUs on different network segments. Configure network edges (CAN channels) in the Properties panel.

Q: What happens if an ECU crashes or stops? A: The ECU Status panel shows the error state (red indicator). Check the Console panel for error messages. You can restart the ECU from the context menu.

Q: Can I modify ECU configuration while it's running? A: Some changes require stopping the ECU first (e.g., network configuration). Others may take effect on restart. Stop the ECU, modify properties, save the system, then restart.

docs.title: ECU Monitoring & Terminal Access
docs.text:
Q: Why can't I connect to an ECU terminal? A: Verify the ECU is running (green status). Check Console logs for terminal service errors. Some ECU images may not have terminal support enabled. Ensure appropriate permissions.

Q: How do I filter logs from a specific ECU? A: In the Console panel, type the ECU name in the filter bar. You can also use log level toggles to show only errors, warnings, etc.

Q: Can I export monitoring data? A: Yes. Export Console logs as text/CSV. Export Resource Monitor metrics as CSV or PNG. Export Network Traffic as BLF, MDF4, or CSV.

Q: Why are my resource graphs showing zero? A: Ensure ECUs are running. Check that the Resource Monitor panel is visible and time range includes recent activity. Refresh the panel if needed.

Q: How do I access terminal for multiple ECUs? A: The Terminal panel has one tab per ECU. Click different tabs to switch between ECU terminals. Each tab maintains its own connection and command history.

Q: Can I run automated commands in terminals? A: Terminal access is interactive. For automation, consider using the CLI tools or scripting against the TrueFidelity APIs (if available in your edition).

docs.title: Miscellaneous
docs.text:
Q: Can I integrate scripts or automation? A: Some editions include CLI utilities. Consult your release notes or support representative for availability.

Q: Does TrueFidelity support other bus types (LIN, FlexRay)? A: Support varies by release. Check the release notes or contact support for the current bus compatibility list.

Q: How do I change the Catppuccin theme colors? A: Edit docs/styles/extra.css or use Settings → Theme if exposed in your build.

docs.text: TrueFidelity supports numerous log, definition, and export formats. Use this reference to understand capabilities, limitations, and best practices.

docs.title: Supported Log Formats
docs.text: Format Extension Notes MDF4 .mf4, .mdf Recommended for large datasets; supports metadata and multiple buses. BLF .blf Vector Binary Logger format; efficient for long captures. ASC .asc Text-based; easy to inspect manually but larger in size. CSV .csv Column-based logs; requires column mapping during import. CANalyzer Logging .log Support varies by release (converted internally).

docs.title: Import Tips
docs.text:
• Place logs on local SSD storage to improve load times.
  • For CSV, map columns to timestamp, ID, DLC, payload, and channel when prompted.
  • If timestamps are relative, use the Normalize option to align to absolute time.

docs.title: Definition Formats
docs.text: Format Extension Notes DBC .dbc Primary method for decoding signals; supports tags and comments. ARXML .arxml Partial support; complex structures may require preprocessing. JSON/XML Varies Custom mapping supported if provided by your distribution.

docs.title: Export Formats
docs.text: Export Extension Usage Segment CSV .csv Share subsets with spreadsheets or scripts. Segment MDF4 .mf4 Maintain binary fidelity for analytics tools. Message CSV .csv Filtered frames from Messages panel. Annotation CSV .csv Documentation of bookmarks and notes. Report .pdf, .html Formal output suitable for reviews. Injection Profile .tfinject Saved injection scenarios. Layout .tflayout Saved workspace arrangements.

docs.title: Mixed-Bus / Multi-Channel Logs
docs.text:
• TrueFidelity supports multiple CAN channels within a single file.
  • Channel metadata is displayed in the Messages panel and timeline.
  • Use filters to analyze one channel at a time if the bus is noisy.

docs.title: Handling Very Large Files
docs.text:
• MDF4 and BLF are most efficient for large logs (>10 GB).
  • Use Incremental Loading to decode on demand.
  • Split logs into chunks using the export feature if your system has limited RAM.

docs.title: Compatibility Matrix
docs.text: Feature MDF4 BLF ASC CSV Signal decoding ✔ ✔ ✔ Requires mapping Multi-channel ✔ ✔ ✔ (with metadata) ✔ High-frequency support ✔ ✔ Limited (text parsing) Depends on sampling Compression ✔ ✔ ✖ ✖ Append mode ✖ ✔ (Vector loggers) ✖ ✔ (manual)

docs.title: Conversion Tools
docs.text:
• Use vendor utilities or open-source tools (e.g., mdfconvert, can-utils) to convert between formats.
  • After conversion, re-import into TrueFidelity to confirm fidelity before archiving original logs.

docs.title: Time Synchronization
docs.text:
• Logs may use absolute or relative timestamps. Use the normalization options to align them.
  • For multi-logger setups, export to a synced format (MDF4 with global time) or provide offset metadata.

docs.title: Known Limitations
docs.text:
• Extremely large CSV files (>2 GB) may load slowly due to text parsing overhead.
  • Some ARXML constructs (complex data types) require preprocessing; contact your data team for supported converters.
  • Logs with encrypted payloads must be decrypted before import; TrueFidelity does not include decryption utilities.

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
• Keep a manifest of captured logs (file name, format, channels, description, checksum).
  • Use consistent naming conventions, e.g., YYYYMMDD_vehicle_testcase_runX.mf4.
  • Store original logs in an immutable location; analyze copies to prevent accidental edits.
  • Record tool versions used for capture and analysis for reproducibility.

docs.title: Related Pages
docs.text:
• Settings – Configure import/export defaults.
  • Performance Tips – Optimize handling of large or numerous files.
  • Glossary – Definitions for terms like MDF, DBC, and payload.

docs.title: Glossary
docs.text: Key terms used throughout the TrueFidelity documentation.

docs.title: A
docs.text:
Annotation – A user-created note tied to a specific timestamp or range, including title, description, tags, and optional attachments.

Autosave – Automatic saving of project state at defined intervals.

docs.title: B
docs.text:
Bookmark – A lightweight marker on the timeline with a title and timestamp.

Burst (Injection) – Schedule sending multiple messages rapidly followed by a pause.

docs.title: C
docs.text:
CAN Frame – A single message on a CAN bus, defined by ID, DLC, payload, timestamp, and flags.

Charts panel – Visualization area plotting decoded signals over time.

Command Palette – Global search interface for commands (Ctrl/Cmd + P).

CSV – Comma-separated values text format for logs or exports.

docs.title: D
docs.text:
Data Injection – Feature that transmits CAN frames from TrueFidelity to simulate or modify traffic.

DBC – CAN database file defining messages, signals, scaling, and metadata.

Derived Signal – A calculated signal based on other signals or raw data via custom formulas.

docs.title: E
docs.text:
Export Queue – Panel managing pending export tasks (segments, reports, etc.).

Export Segment – Export of a selected timeline range to CSV/MDF.

docs.title: F
docs.text:
Filter-to-Range – Restricts visible data to the currently selected timeline segment.

Floating Panel – Panel detached from the main window, useful on multi-monitor setups.

docs.title: G
docs.text: Glossary – This page, containing definitions of commonly used terms.

docs.title: H
docs.text: Heartbeat – Periodic message ensuring systems remain synchronized; often simulated during injection.

docs.title: I
docs.text:
Injection Profile – Saved configuration (.tfinject) containing message templates and schedules.

Interval (Injection) – Schedule sending messages at a fixed cadence.

docs.title: L
docs.text:
Layout – Arrangement of panels saved within a project; interchangeable via the layout switcher.

Loop Mode – Playback mode that repeats the selected timeline range.

docs.title: M
docs.text:
MDF4 – Measurement Data Format 4, binary log format optimized for large datasets.

Messages panel – Displays raw CAN frames with filtering and export capabilities.

docs.title: N
docs.text: Normalization – Process of aligning timestamps (absolute vs. relative) during import.

docs.title: P
docs.text:
Payload – Raw byte content of a CAN frame.

Pinned Signal – Signal saved to the watch list for quick access.

Playback Buffer – Number of frames preloaded for smooth playback.

Profile (Layout) – Saved workspace arrangement or injection configuration.

docs.title: R
docs.text:
Ramp (Injection) – Schedule that gradually changes message rate over time.

Report Builder – Tool generating PDF/HTML summaries including annotations, charts, and metrics.

docs.title: S
docs.text:
Segment – Time selection on the timeline used for playback looping or export.

Signals panel – Interface for searching, pinning, and managing decoded signals.

Snapshot – Screenshot of charts or panels stored in the export folder.

docs.title: T
docs.text:
Timeline – Topmost bar showing playback progress, selections, and markers.

Transport Controls – Play, pause, step, and loop buttons located in the footer.

TrueFidelity Project (.tfproj) – File storing project configuration, layout references, filters, and metadata.

docs.title: U
docs.text: UI Scaling – Setting controlling interface size for accessibility.

docs.title: V
docs.text: Verbose Logging – Enhanced logging mode for troubleshooting.

docs.title: W
docs.text:
Watch List – Collection of pinned signals displayed in the sidebar.

Workspace – The overall UI environment containing panels, timeline, and controls.

docs.title: Z
docs.text: Zero-copy Import – Links files without copying, preserving disk space (default behavior when importing logs).

docs.title: Performance Tips
docs.text: Optimize TrueFidelity for smooth playback, fast exports, and responsive UI by following the practices below.

docs.title: Hardware Recommendations
docs.text:
• Storage: Use NVMe or SSD drives for log storage. Avoid network drives during analysis.
  • Memory: 16 GB minimum; 32 GB recommended for large logs or multiple charts.
  • CPU: 6–8 cores at 3 GHz or higher. More cores improve export and decoding speeds.
  • GPU: A modern GPU with updated drivers accelerates rendering. Integrated GPUs are supported but may limit chart density.

docs.title: Project Organization
docs.text:
• Store projects and related logs on the same drive to reduce cross-disk latency.
  • Archive completed logs to external storage to keep active workspace lean.
  • Use relative paths in projects to avoid re-indexing when moving between machines.

docs.title: Playback Optimization
docs.text:
• Adjust Playback buffer size (Settings → Playback). Increase for large sequential reads; decrease for quick scrubbing.
  • Disable unnecessary panels during playback (e.g., close Data Injection if not in use).
  • Use Filter to Range to limit the dataset rendered.
  • Switch charts to Fixed scale for steady redrawing if auto-scale causes flicker.

docs.title: Filtering & Decoding
docs.text:
• Apply broad filters first (by channel or time) before adding complex payload rules.
  • Enable Incremental decoding so TrueFidelity decodes frames on demand.
  • Pre-process text-based logs (ASC, CSV) to remove extraneous columns.

docs.title: Charts & Visuals
docs.text:
• Limit the number of simultaneously plotted signals. Combine related signals onto one axis when practical.
  • Reduce marker density; disable markers unless needed for presentations.
  • Enable Downsampling in Settings → Charts to cap the number of points drawn.

docs.title: Exports
docs.text:
• Batch exports overnight using the Export Queue.
  • Export shorter segments instead of full logs when only a portion is needed.
  • Choose binary formats (MDF4) for large datasets—faster to write and smaller on disk.
  • For CSV, reduce decimal precision to minimize file size and export time.

docs.title: Data Injection
docs.text:
• Run injection from a dedicated machine if possible to avoid competing for resources with playback.
  • Set realistic rate limits; extremely high rates can saturate the interface and cause backlog.
  • Monitor hardware status indicators for bus-off conditions; if detected, pause injection and allow hardware to recover.

docs.title: System Maintenance
docs.text:
• Keep OS, drivers, and firmware updated.
  • Disable background processes that can hog disk or CPU (cloud sync, indexing) during critical sessions.
  • Use high-performance power mode on laptops to avoid throttling.

docs.title: Troubleshooting Slowness
docs.text: Symptom Troubleshooting Steps Playback stutters Reduce playback speed, close heavy panels, move logs to faster storage. Charts lag Limit to essential signals, increase downsampling, check GPU driver updates. Export queue stuck Verify disk space, close other applications, check logs for errors. UI unresponsive during large imports Import in chunks or pre-convert to binary formats.

docs.title: Logging & Diagnostics
docs.text:
• Enable Verbose logging (Settings → Diagnostics) when investigating performance issues.
  • Review system resource usage via OS tools (Task Manager, Activity Monitor, top).
  • Include logs when contacting support to speed up diagnosis.

docs.title: Automation
docs.text:
• Schedule CLI exports or conversions during off-hours using OS schedulers.
  • Use scripts to pre-filter logs before loading them into TrueFidelity.

docs.title: Collaboration
docs.text:
• Share performance tuning guidelines with your team so everyone uses consistent practices.
  • Maintain a centralized knowledge base containing optimal settings for various workloads.

docs.title: Related Resources
docs.text:
• Settings – Adjust playback buffer, downsampling, and autosave.
  • Troubleshooting – Common causes and solutions for performance-related issues.
  • Support – Contact channels for assistance with persistent performance problems.

docs.title: Settings Reference
docs.text: Customize TrueFidelity to match your workflow using the Settings dialog. This reference covers each category and notable options.

docs.title: General
docs.text:
• Language – UI language; restart may be required.
  • Theme – Choose between light, dark, or custom palettes (e.g., Catppuccin).
  • Autosave interval – Frequency at which projects auto-save (1–30 minutes). Set to 0 to disable.
  • Recent items limit – Number of recent projects and files shown.
  • Telemetry – Opt in/out of anonymous usage metrics (if offered in your distribution).

docs.title: Workspace
docs.text:
• Default layout – Layout applied to new projects. Choose from saved layouts.
  • Docking behavior – Adjust drag sensitivity to prevent accidental undocking.
  • Panel animations – Enable/disable transition animations when docking panels.

docs.title: Playback
docs.text:
• Default speed – Initial playback rate (1× recommended).
  • Resume playback on open – If enabled, playback starts when you reopen a project.
  • Loop selection by default – Automatically loop selected ranges.
  • Buffer size – Number of frames cached during playback; increase for smoother playback on high-IO systems.

docs.title: Data & Import
docs.text:
• Copy imported files – Copy logs into the project folder or reference original path.
  • Normalize timestamps – Automatically convert relative timestamps to absolute when importing.
  • Default channel naming – Set naming scheme for new channels (e.g., CAN_A, CAN_B).
  • CSV column presets – Save column mappings for recurring CSV imports.

docs.title: Charts
docs.text:
• Theme – Choose color palettes for signals (e.g., color-blind friendly)."
  • Anti-aliasing – Smooth lines for readability; disable for performance.
  • Max samples – Limit number of points drawn to maintain performance.
  • Cursor appearance – Customize color and width of measurement cursors.

docs.title: Messages
docs.text:
• Timestamp display – Choose absolute, relative, or delta timestamps.
  • Payload formatting – Hex with spaces, continuous hex, or ASCII preview.
  • Auto-freeze threshold – Optionally freeze scrolling when message rate exceeds a set value.
  • Persist filters – Reapply last-used filters when reopening a project.

docs.title: Annotations
docs.text:
• Default tags – Pre-populate tags for new annotations (e.g., needs-review).
  • Severity levels – Configure labels and colors (critical, major, minor).
  • Template directory – Path where annotation templates are stored.

docs.title: Data Injection
docs.text:
• Default channel – Preselect a channel when opening the injection panel.
  • Safety prompts – Enable extra confirmations before starting injection.
  • Rate limiter – Cap maximum injection frequency for safety.
  • Profile storage – Default path for .tfinject files.

docs.title: Exports
docs.text:
• Default export folder – Directory used when no path is specified.
  • Filename template – Use tokens like {project}, {range}, {timestamp} to automate naming.
  • CSV delimiter – Choose comma, semicolon, or tab.
  • Include filter summary – Append active filters to export metadata.

docs.title: Reports
docs.text:
• Default template – Template preselected in Report Builder.
  • Branding assets – Logos or cover images applied to exported reports.
  • Auto-embed screenshots – Automatically include latest chart captures when building reports.

docs.title: Shortcuts
docs.text:
• Customize keyboard mappings for commands, panels, and playback.
  • Export/import shortcut profiles (.tfkeys).

docs.title: Accessibility
docs.text:
• High-contrast focus – Enhances focus outlines for keyboard navigation.
  • UI scaling – Scale the interface (80–150%).
  • Reduced motion – Disable panel animations for sensitive users.
  • Screen reader hints – Enable additional UI hints for screen reader compatibility.

docs.title: Updates
docs.text:
• Auto-check for updates – Enable to receive release notifications.
  • Channel selection – Choose stable, beta, or nightly channels (requires permission).
  • Download path – Location where installers are stored.

docs.title: Diagnostics
docs.text:
• Verbose logging – Increase log detail for troubleshooting (impacts performance slightly).
  • Log retention – Number of days to keep log files before automatic cleanup.
  • Hardware monitoring – Toggle display of CPU/GPU utilization overlay.

docs.title: Reset & Recovery
docs.text:
• Restore defaults – Reset all settings to factory values.
  • Backup settings – Export current settings to JSON for safekeeping.
  • Import settings – Apply settings from a previously saved file.

docs.title: Tips for Managing Settings
docs.text:
• Document organizational defaults in a shared guideline.
  • Store exported settings alongside projects to recreate environments quickly.
  • Review settings quarterly to adopt new features introduced by updates.

docs.title: Related Pages
docs.text:
• Performance Tips – Optimizing playback and exports based on settings choices.
  • Troubleshooting – Where to adjust options when issues arise.
  • Glossary – Definitions for settings terminology.

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text: Use this guide to resolve common TrueFidelity issues. If problems persist, gather logs and contact support.

docs.title: Before You Begin
docs.text:
1. Confirm you’re running the latest approved version. Check Help → About.
  2. Reproduce the issue and note the exact steps, timestamps, and files involved.
  3. Open Help → Show Logs; keep the folder ready for support if needed.

docs.title: Installer Fails or Freezes
docs.text:
• Run the installer as administrator (Windows) or using sudo (Linux).
  • Disable antivirus temporarily if it quarantines installer components.
  • Verify disk space and permissions in the target directory.

docs.title: Application Won’t Start
docs.text:
• Launch from a terminal to view error output (truefidelity --verbose).
  • Update graphics drivers; try launching with --disable-gpu or --safe-mode.
  • Reset settings by deleting the configuration file under your user profile (document before removal).

docs.title: Playback Stutters
docs.text:
• Reduce playback speed or limit visible panels.
  • Move logs to faster storage (SSD/NVMe).
  • Enable Incremental decoding in settings.
  • Check CPU/GPU usage for bottlenecks.

docs.title: Timeline Jumps Erratically
docs.text:
• Normalize timestamps when importing logs.
  • Confirm logs are not using different time bases; apply offsets if necessary.
  • Disable conflicting filters that might skip large sections.

docs.title: Annotations Missing After Restart
docs.text:
• Ensure autosave is enabled or manually save before closing.
  • Check project folder permissions; if read-only, TrueFidelity can’t save updates.

docs.title: Charts Blank or Frozen
docs.text:
• Reset layout to reinitialize panels.
  • Remove overloaded signal sets and re-add critical ones.
  • Update GPU drivers; disable hardware acceleration if necessary.

docs.title: Signal Not Decoding
docs.text:
• Verify the correct DBC is imported and prioritized.
  • Ensure the message uses the expected ID (standard vs. extended).
  • Check for conflicting definitions; disable duplicates temporarily.

docs.title: ECU Won't Start
docs.text:
• Verify Docker Desktop is running and accessible.
  • Check Console panel for error messages from the container.
  • Ensure binary path is correct and file exists (if specified).
  • Verify system has available resources (CPU, memory, Docker limits).
  • Try starting ECUs one at a time to isolate issues.

docs.title: System Canvas Won't Save
docs.text:
• Check file permissions on the save location.
  • Verify no other instance has the system file open.
  • Ensure sufficient disk space.
  • Try saving to a different location as a test.

docs.title: Network Connections Not Working
docs.text:
• Verify network edges are properly connected in System Canvas.
  • Check network properties (baud rate, channel assignments).
  • Ensure ECUs are running before expecting traffic.
  • Review Network Traffic panel for actual message flow.

docs.title: Build Failures
docs.text:
• Check Build Console panel for compilation errors.
  • Verify build target is correct for your hardware.
  • Ensure toolchain is properly installed and configured.
  • Review ECU properties for correct source paths and compiler options.

docs.title: ECU Status Shows "Error" or Won't Start
docs.text:
• Open Console panel and filter to that ECU.
  • Look for error messages indicating the cause (missing binary, port conflicts, resource limits).
  • Check Docker logs: docker ps -a and docker logs <container-id>.
  • Verify container resources aren't exhausted (memory, CPU limits).

docs.title: Console Logs Not Appearing
docs.text:
• Verify ECU is running (green status in ECU Status panel).
  • Check Console panel filters aren't hiding all messages.
  • Ensure log level toggles include the message types you expect.
  • Try refreshing the Console panel or reconnecting.

docs.title: Resource Monitor Shows Zero or No Data
docs.text:
• Ensure ECUs are actually running (not just defined).
  • Check time range includes recent activity (adjust dropdown).
  • Verify Resource Monitor panel is visible and not minimized.
  • Restart ECUs to reset metrics collection.

docs.title: Terminal Connection Fails
docs.text:
• Verify ECU is running (green status).
  • Check Console logs for terminal service errors.
  • Some ECU images don't have terminal support—verify image capabilities.
  • Try reconnecting using the reconnect button in Terminal panel.
  • Check Docker networking: ensure sidecar containers are running.

docs.title: Network Traffic Empty
docs.text:
• Ensure ECUs are running and connected via network edges.
  • Check Network Traffic panel filters aren't hiding all messages.
  • Verify ECU firmware is actually sending CAN messages.
  • Check that network type (CAN/Ethernet) matches configuration.
  • Review Console logs for network interface errors.

docs.title: Process Monitor Shows No Processes
docs.text:
• Ensure correct ECU is selected.
  • Verify ECU has a running operating system (some minimal images may not support process monitoring).
  • Check that Process Monitor service is enabled for that ECU.

docs.title: Injection Not Starting
docs.text:
• Confirm license includes injection feature.
  • Ensure hardware is connected and not in monitor-only mode.
  • Review injection profile for invalid IDs or payload formatting.

docs.title: Injection Stops with Errors
docs.text:
• Inspect the injection log for bus-off or permission errors.
  • Reduce frequency; high rates may saturate the bus.
  • Restart the CAN interface or power-cycle hardware.

docs.title: Export Queue Stuck
docs.text:
• Verify destination drive has free space and write permissions.
  • Cancel the offending task and retry.
  • Check logs for file path errors.

docs.title: Report Missing Images
docs.text:
• Ensure screenshots referenced in the report remain in the project folder.
  • Rebuild the report after adding missing assets.

docs.title: Panel Missing
docs.text:
• Use View → Reset Layout.
  • If using multiple monitors, ensure the OS still detects all displays.

docs.title: Shortcuts Not Working
docs.text:
• Check for conflicts in Settings → Shortcuts.
  • On macOS, ensure the key combination isn’t reserved by the OS.

docs.title: Performance Degradation Over Time
docs.text:
• Clear the Messages panel filters and reduce chart complexity.
  • Restart TrueFidelity to release cached resources.
  • Update to the latest patch that may include performance fixes.

docs.title: Logging & Diagnostics
docs.text:
• Enable Verbose logging in Settings → Diagnostics for extra detail.
  • Use Help → Copy Support Bundle if available to gather logs automatically.
  • Include system information (OS version, CPU, RAM, GPU) when reporting issues.

docs.title: Contacting Support
docs.text:
1. Prepare the following:
  2. Brief issue description and steps to reproduce
  3. Screenshots or screen recordings
  4. Project file (.tfproj) or sanitized sample log if possible
  5. Log bundle ZIP
  6. Submit through your official support portal or email.
  7. Reference any related ticket numbers or change requests.

docs.title: Quick Reference Table
docs.text: Symptom Quick Fix App launches but nothing renders Run with --disable-gpu, update drivers. ECU won't start Check Docker is running, review Console logs, verify binary path. Terminal connection fails Verify ECU is running, check Console for errors, try reconnect. Resource Monitor shows zero Ensure ECUs running, adjust time range, refresh panel. Network traffic empty Verify network edges connected, check filters, ensure ECUs sending messages. Signals missing Re-import DBC, check priority order. Export empty Verify timeline range and filters. Crash on exit Delete temp files from %AppData%/TrueFidelity/cache (Windows) or ~/Library/Application Support/TrueFidelity/cache (macOS).
