  • Support – Contact information and escalation paths.
  • Settings – Adjust defaults to prevent recurring issues.

docs.title: ECU Monitoring Walkthrough
docs.text: This tutorial focuses on monitoring and debugging running ECU systems in TrueFidelity. You'll learn to use monitoring panels effectively to track performance, diagnose issues, and gather diagnostic data.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Goal: Monitor a running ECU system, use filtering and analysis tools, access terminals for debugging, and export monitoring data.

Time estimate: 10-15 minutes

Prerequisites: - A running ECU system (or follow the System Design Workflow tutorial first) - TrueFidelity installed and activated

docs.title: Step 1: Set Up Monitoring Layout
docs.text:
Before monitoring, organize your panels for optimal visibility:

  1. Open View → Reset Layout to start with defaults
  2. Open the following panels:
  3. ECU Status (Ctrl/Cmd + 1)
  4. Console (Ctrl/Cmd + 2)
  5. Resource Monitor (Ctrl/Cmd + 3)
  6. Network Traffic (if monitoring CAN)

  7. Terminal (Ctrl/Cmd + 4)

  8. Arrange panels to your preference:

  9. Drag panel tabs to reposition
  10. Resize panels by dragging edges

  11. Split views by dragging to edge docking zones

  12. Save this layout: View → Save Layout As... → name it "Monitoring"

Tip

Create different layouts for different monitoring scenarios (e.g., "Performance Monitoring", "Debugging Layout").

docs.title: Step 2: Monitor ECU Status
docs.text: The ECU Status panel provides an overview of all ECUs in your system.

docs.title: Understanding Status Indicators
docs.text:
1. Open ECU Status panel
  2. Observe status colors:
  3. Green: Running normally
  4. Yellow: Starting up
  5. Red: Error state
  6. Gray: Stopped

docs.title: Quick Actions
docs.text:
1. Right-click any ECU in the status table
  2. Context menu options:
  3. Start: Launch the ECU container
  4. Stop: Gracefully shutdown
  5. Restart: Stop then start
  6. View Logs: Open ECU-specific console view
  7. Terminal: Open terminal tab for this ECU
  8. Properties: View detailed configuration

docs.title: Resource Summary
docs.text:
1. Hover over CPU% or Memory cells
  2. Tooltip shows detailed metrics
  3. Sort columns by clicking headers to identify resource-heavy ECUs

docs.title: Step 3: Analyze Console Logs
docs.text: The Console panel aggregates logs from all ECUs.

docs.title: Filtering Logs
docs.text:
1. Open Console panel
  2. In the filter bar, type an ECU name (e.g., gateway)
  1. Only logs from that ECU are shown
  2. Clear filter to see all logs again

docs.title: Filter by Log Level
docs.text:
1. Use log level toggles (Info, Warn, Error, Debug)
  2. Uncheck Info to focus on warnings and errors
  3. Check only Error to see critical issues

docs.title: Search Logs
docs.text:
1. Click in the search box
  2. Type a keyword (e.g., timeout, error, CAN)
  3. Matching lines are highlighted
  4. Use arrow keys to navigate between matches

docs.title: Export Logs
docs.text:
1. Apply desired filters
  2. Click Export button (or right-click → Export)
  3. Choose format:
  4. Text file: Plain text with timestamps
  5. CSV: For analysis in spreadsheet tools
  6. Save filtered logs for later analysis

Tip

Export logs periodically during long test runs to avoid losing data if the app crashes.

docs.title: Step 4: Track Resource Usage
docs.text: The Resource Monitor shows real-time CPU and memory trends.

docs.title: Reading the Graphs
docs.text:
1. Open Resource Monitor panel
  1. Each ECU has a colored line:
  2. CPU usage as percentage
  3. Memory usage in megabytes
  4. X-axis shows time, Y-axis shows usage percentage/amount

docs.title: Adjust Time Range
docs.text:
1. Use dropdown to select:
  2. 1 minute: Short-term spikes
  3. 5 minutes: Recent activity
  4. 15 minutes: Medium-term trends
  5. 1 hour: Long-term patterns

docs.title: Zoom into Specific Periods
docs.text:
1. Click and drag on the graph to select a time range
  2. Graph zooms to that range
  3. Click Reset Zoom to return to full view

docs.title: Identify Issues
docs.text:
• CPU spikes: Sudden increases may indicate processing bottlenecks
  • Memory leaks: Gradually increasing memory suggests memory leaks
  • Resource contention: Multiple ECUs high usage simultaneously

docs.title: Export Metrics
docs.text:
1. Click Export button
  2. Choose format:
  3. CSV: For Excel or Python analysis
  4. PNG: For reports and presentations
  5. Exported data includes all visible time range

docs.title: Step 5: Monitor Network Traffic
docs.text: The Network Traffic panel shows CAN messages in real-time.

docs.title: View Live Messages
docs.text:
1. Open Network Traffic panel
  2. Messages appear as they're transmitted
  3. Columns show: Timestamp, ID, DLC, Payload, Channel, Source

docs.title: Filter Messages
docs.text:
1. In filter bar, enter:
  2. Message ID: 0x123 or 291 (decimal)
  3. Channel: can0, can1
  4. Source ECU: ECU name
  5. Only matching messages are shown

docs.title: Analyze Message Rates
docs.text:
1. Watch the Rate column (messages/second)
  2. High rates may indicate excessive traffic
  3. Zero rates might indicate a broken connection

docs.title: View Signal Decoding
docs.text:
1. Load a DBC file: Project → Import Definitions
  2. Signals are decoded and displayed below raw payload
  3. Click message to see decoded signal values

docs.title: Capture Traffic to Log
docs.text:
1. Click Start Capture
  2. Traffic is recorded to memory
  3. Click Stop Capture
  4. Click Export to save as:
  5. BLF: Vector format
  6. MDF4: MDF format
  7. CSV: Spreadsheet format

docs.title: Step 6: Use Terminal Access
docs.text: The Terminal panel provides shell access to ECU operating systems.

docs.title: Connect to ECU
docs.text:
1. Open Terminal panel
  2. Tabs show one terminal per ECU
  3. Click tab for the ECU you want to access
  4. Connection status indicator shows:
  5. Green: Connected
  6. Yellow: Connecting
  7. Red: Connection failed

docs.title: Run Diagnostic Commands
docs.text:
Once connected, try these commands:

# Check CPU usage
top

# View memory info
cat /proc/meminfo

# List processes
ps aux

# Check network interfaces
ifconfig

# View recent log messages
dmesg | tail -20

# Check disk space
df -h

docs.title: Search Terminal Output
docs.text:
1. Press Ctrl+F (Cmd+F on macOS)
  2. Search box appears
  3. Type search term
  4. Matching text is highlighted
  5. Use arrow keys to navigate matches

docs.title: Terminal Actions
docs.text:
• Clear: Button clears terminal screen (history preserved)
  • Copy: Select text with mouse, use Ctrl/Cmd+C
  • Reconnect: If connection drops, click reconnect button

Warning

Some commands may require root privileges. Be cautious with system modifications.

docs.title: ECU Not Starting
docs.text:
1. Check ECU Status panel for error state
  2. Open Console panel, filter to that ECU
  3. Look for error messages
  4. Check resource limits in Properties panel

docs.title: High Resource Usage
docs.text:
1. Open Resource Monitor
  2. Identify which ECU is using resources
  3. Open Terminal for that ECU
  4. Run top to see process breakdown
  5. Check for runaway processes or memory leaks

docs.title: Network Issues
docs.text:
1. Check Network Traffic panel for messages
  2. If no messages, verify:
  3. Network edges are connected in System Canvas
  4. ECU firmware is sending messages
  5. Filters aren't hiding all traffic
  6. Check Console logs for network errors

docs.title: Terminal Connection Problems
docs.text:
1. Verify ECU is running (green in ECU Status)
  2. Check Console for terminal service errors
  3. Try reconnecting from Terminal panel
  4. Some ECU images may not support terminals

docs.title: Create Monitoring Report
docs.text:
1. Export from each panel:
  2. Console: Text/CSV logs
  3. Resource Monitor: CSV metrics or PNG graphs
  4. Network Traffic: BLF/MDF4 capture
  5. Combine exports into a report document

docs.title: Automated Data Collection
docs.text:
For long test runs:

  1. Set Resource Monitor time range to capture full duration
  2. Periodically export Console logs
  3. Capture Network Traffic at key moments
  4. Save Terminal command outputs

docs.title: Organize Panels by Task
docs.text:
• Development: Canvas, Properties, Build Console
  • Monitoring: ECU Status, Console, Resource Monitor
  • Debugging: Terminal, Process Monitor, Console
  • Analysis: Network Traffic, Signal Viewer, Charts

docs.title: Use Filters Effectively
docs.text:
• Don't filter too aggressively—you might miss important events
  • Save filter presets for common scenarios
  • Combine multiple filters for precise analysis

docs.title: Export Regularly
docs.text:
• Don't wait until the end to export data
  • Periodic exports prevent data loss
  • Name exports with timestamps for organization

docs.title: Monitor Baselines
docs.text:
• Establish normal resource usage baselines
  • Compare current metrics to baselines to spot anomalies
  • Track trends over time

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Learn advanced panel customization in Workspaces & Layouts
  • Explore build and deployment in System Design Workflow
  • Review Performance Tips for optimizing monitoring
  • Read Troubleshooting guide for common issues

docs.title: End-to-End Example
docs.text: This tutorial walks through a complete TrueFidelity workflow: project creation, playback analysis, signal inspection, data injection, annotation, and reporting. Expect to spend 20–30 minutes.

docs.title: Scenario
docs.text: You’re investigating intermittent braking anomalies captured during a proving-ground test. You have: - Two CAN log files (baseline and suspect run) - A DBC file with signal definitions - A test plan requiring annotations, injection replay, and a formal report

docs.title: Step 1 – Prepare the Project
docs.text:
1. Create a new project named Brake-Analysis in your project workspace.
  2. Import the baseline log (baseline.mf4) and the suspect log (suspect.mf4).
  3. Import the braking.dbc definition file.
  4. Save the project.

docs.title: Step 2 – Configure Layout
docs.text:
1. Load the Analysis layout (or create one):
  2. Timeline top
  3. Messages left
  4. Charts right
  5. Signals docked below Messages
  6. Annotations bottom
  7. Pin key signals: brake_pedal, wheel_speed_fl, wheel_speed_fr, hydraulic_pressure.
  8. Drag the pinned signals into Charts.

docs.title: Step 3 – Compare Baseline vs. Suspect
docs.text:
1. Enable both logs; color-coding distinguishes them.
  2. Align them by timestamp. Use the Align logs feature with the start of the test run.
  3. Play both logs at 1× speed.
  4. Watch for diverging wheel speeds or pressure spikes.
  5. Pause when you spot a discrepancy (e.g., hydraulic pressure spike without pedal input).

docs.title: Step 4 – Annotate Events
docs.text:
1. Add an annotation named “Pressure spike without pedal” at the anomaly.
  2. Tag with braking, investigate, suspect.
  3. Capture a chart screenshot for later.
  4. Add a bookmark slightly earlier labeled “Baseline reference” for comparison.

docs.title: Step 5 – Filter for Related Signals
docs.text:
1. Apply a message filter for IDs associated with the braking ECU.
  2. Enable Filter to Range around the anomaly (10 seconds window).
  3. Inspect payload differences between baseline and suspect logs.
  4. Add a second annotation if you notice a diagnostic code or unusual payload bit set.

docs.title: Step 6 – Injection Reproduction (Bench Setup)
docs.text:
1. Switch to the Injection layout (Data Injection panel left, Messages center, Charts right).
  2. Create a message template replicating the suspect payload.
  3. Configure a burst schedule: send 20 frames at 20 Hz.
  4. Start injection on the bench ECU (ensure it’s disconnected from the vehicle).
  5. Monitor the ECU response. Chart hydraulic_pressure and brake_warning_flag signals (from live feed or recorded response).
  6. Annotate the start/end of the injection and note whether the anomaly reproduces.

docs.title: Step 7 – Export Data
docs.text:
1. Select the anomaly range on the timeline.
  2. Export to CSV with decoded signals and annotations included.
  3. Export annotation CSV for the entire session.
  4. Save injection profile (pressure_spike_replay.tfinject) for future use.

docs.title: Step 8 – Build the Report
docs.text:
1. Open Report Builder.
  2. Choose the Validation template.
  3. Fill in overview information: test objective, logs used, hardware setup.
  4. Add the annotations created earlier.
  5. Insert the chart screenshot showing baseline vs. suspect difference.
  6. Attach the CSV export and injection profile as supporting files.
  7. Generate the PDF report and review for accuracy.

docs.title: Step 9 – Archive & Share
docs.text:
1. Save the project.
  2. Zip the project folder including exports, profiles, and report.
  3. Upload to your collaboration platform or attach to the investigation ticket.
  4. Document next steps (e.g., replicate on hardware-in-the-loop rig).

docs.title: Reflection
docs.text:
• What triggered the anomaly? Document hypotheses in the project notes.
  • Did the injection reproduce the issue? If not, what differed between bench and road conditions?
  • Are additional logs needed? Plan follow-up captures if necessary.

docs.title: Variations
docs.text:
• Swap logs to evaluate other subsystems (steering, acceleration).
  • Extend the workflow with automated CLI exports.
  • Integrate hardware signals from auxiliary bus captures (LIN, FlexRay) if your build supports it.

docs.title: Next Tutorials
docs.text:
• Playback Analysis Walkthrough – Focuses on deep-dive signal inspection.
  • Injection Scenario Walkthrough – Broader injection scenario with safety guardrails.
  • Report Builder Deep Dive – Customize templates and embed corporate branding.

docs.title: Injection Scenario Walkthrough
docs.text: This tutorial demonstrates how to design, execute, and analyze a controlled data injection scenario. Estimated time: 25 minutes.

docs.title: Scenario
docs.text: A suspension controller occasionally fails to set a diagnostic flag when subjected to a specific message pattern. Engineers suspect timing jitter on a CAN frame is responsible. Goal: recreate the pattern using injection, confirm the fault, and document results.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Bench setup with the suspension controller connected to can0
  • TrueFidelity with injection feature enabled
  • DBC file suspension.dbc
  • Baseline log capturing normal behavior

docs.title: Step 1 – Project Setup
docs.text:
1. Create a project Suspension-Injection-Test.
  2. Import baseline_suspension.mf4 and suspension.dbc.
  3. Load the Injection layout (Data Injection panel left, Messages center, Charts right).

docs.title: Step 2 – Analyze Baseline
docs.text:
1. Play the baseline log to identify normal timing.
  2. Pin signals: suspension_status, damping_pressure, diagnostic_flag.
  3. Add them to Charts and capture reference screenshots.
  4. Note message ID and interval for the suspect frame (e.g., ID 0x350, every 20 ms).

docs.title: Step 3 – Create Injection Template
docs.text:
1. In Data Injection panel click Add Message.
  2. ID: 0x350, DLC: 8, Payload: AA 00 3C 10 00 00 00 01.
  3. Set channel to can0.
  4. Add a second message template representing the jitter (same ID, different payload bit).

docs.title: Step 4 – Configure Schedules
docs.text:
• Template A (normal message): Interval 20 ms.
  • Template B (jitter): Burst of 3 frames at 5 ms intervals every 200 ms.
  • Ensure Template B runs slightly offset (delay 50 ms) to overlap with Template A.

Tip

Use the preview graph in the injection panel to verify the combined effect of both schedules before starting.

docs.title: Step 5 – Safety Checks
docs.text:
1. Confirm the bench controller is in test mode.
  2. Ensure an emergency stop or power cutoff is within reach.
  3. Announce to teammates that injection is starting.

docs.title: Step 6 – Run Injection
docs.text:
1. Press Start in the injection panel.
  2. Monitor counters to ensure messages send successfully.
  3. Watch Messages panel filtered for ID 0x350 to verify interval changes.
  4. Observe Charts for diagnostic_flag response.
  5. Let injection run for at least 2 minutes.

docs.title: Step 7 – Annotate Findings
docs.text:
• When the diagnostic flag fails to assert, add an annotation “Diagnostic miss #1”.
  • Note conditions: time, temperature (if available), injection profile version.
  • Add bookmarks for times when the flag works correctly for comparison.

docs.title: Step 8 – Adjust and Retest
docs.text:
1. Stop injection.
  2. Modify Template B burst rate (e.g., increase to 5 frames) and restart.
  3. Record whether the failure becomes more frequent.
  4. Repeat until you establish a reliable reproduction pattern.

docs.title: Step 9 – Export Evidence
docs.text:
1. Export a segment covering a successful reproduction (include annotations).
  2. Export the injection profile (suspension_jitter_profile.tfinject).
  3. Capture chart screenshots showing command vs. diagnostic flag behavior.
  4. Download the injection log from the panel for auditing.

docs.title: Step 10 – Build the Report
docs.text:
1. Launch Report Builder with the Injection Validation template.
  2. Document setup (hardware, firmware versions, environment conditions).
  3. Insert annotations and screenshots.
  4. Attach exported segment, injection profile, and logs.
  5. Summarize findings and recommended next steps (e.g., adjust controller debounce logic).

docs.title: Cleanup
docs.text:
• Stop injection and power down the controller if required.
  • Restore the system to normal operating mode.
  • Commit project changes to version control.

docs.title: Lessons Learned
docs.text:
• Controlled injection can reproduce rare timing issues efficiently.
  • Logging annotations and exporting profiles create a repeatable test package.
  • Combining burst and interval schedules allows complex message patterns without scripting.

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Share the report with the suspension firmware team.
  • Use the same profile on hardware-in-the-loop rigs for broader validation.
  • Explore Safety & Best Practices to formalize injection protocols.

docs.title: Playback Analysis Walkthrough
docs.text: This tutorial focuses on advanced playback analysis techniques—filtering, charting, and comparing signals across multiple logs—to pinpoint anomalies quickly. Estimated time: 15–20 minutes.

docs.title: Scenario
docs.text: You have a 15-minute CAN log from a thermal endurance test. Engineers suspect intermittent cooling fan dropouts leading to engine temperature spikes. Goal: confirm the issue, quantify severity, and prepare a summary.

docs.title: Step 1 – Setup Project & Layout
docs.text:
1. Create a project named Cooling-Fan-Analysis.
  2. Import cooling_run.mf4 and cooling_baseline.mf4.
  3. Import powertrain.dbc.
  4. Load the Analysis layout (Messages left, Charts right, Signals bottom).

docs.title: Step 2 – Pin Key Signals
docs.text:
• engine_coolant_temp
  • cooling_fan_command
  • cooling_fan_feedback
  • vehicle_speed

Add these signals to the chart. Arrange them on separate axes if scale differs significantly.

docs.title: Step 3 – Establish Baseline
docs.text:
1. Mute the suspect log and play the baseline log for two minutes.
  2. Observe normal fan operation: command and feedback align, temperature remains stable.
  3. Add a bookmark “Baseline behavior” at the 2-minute mark.

docs.title: Step 4 – Analyze Suspect Log
docs.text:
1. Enable the suspect log and disable the baseline log.
  2. Set playback speed to 2× to scan quickly.
  3. Watch for divergences between fan command and feedback.

docs.title: Step 5 – Filtering
docs.text:
1. Use the Messages filter builder:
  2. IDs related to cooling module (e.g., 0x421, 0x422).
  3. Time range 00:05:00 to 00:12:00 (suspected window).
  4. Enable Filter to Range so charts update accordingly.
  5. Observe message intervals; look for gaps when feedback drops to zero.

Tip

Highlight frames with fan feedback 0x00 using color rules for quick visual identification.

docs.title: Step 6 – Quantify Temperature Rise
docs.text:
1. When you spot a fan dropout, pause and add an annotation (e.g., “Fan dropout #1”).
  2. Add cursors at the start and end of the temperature spike.
  3. Note the delta (e.g., +12 °C over 45 seconds).
  4. Repeat for subsequent dropouts.

docs.title: Step 7 – Compare Against Baseline
docs.text:
1. Enable both logs simultaneously.
  2. Align via the timeline using the start marker.
  3. Use chart legend to toggle baseline vs. suspect signals for comparison.
  4. Capture a screenshot when dropout occurs to include in the summary.

docs.title: Step 8 – Export Data for Review
docs.text:
1. Select a 60-second range around the worst spike.
  2. Export the segment to CSV with decoded signals.
  3. Export the annotation list (includes dropout timestamps).
  4. Save the chart screenshot to your exports folder.

docs.title: Step 9 – Summarize Findings
docs.text: Create a text summary in project notes or annotations: - Number of dropouts observed - Duration and temperature rise for each event - Impact on vehicle speed or other dependencies - Differences compared to baseline

docs.title: Step 10 – Report
docs.text:
• Launch Report Builder with the Operational Anomaly template.
  • Include annotations, charts, and CSV exports.
  • Add narrative describing root-cause hypothesis (e.g., fan relay overheating).

docs.title: Optional Enhancements
docs.text:
• Use derived signals to calculate fan duty cycle percentage.
  • Apply the batch export feature to process multiple ranges automatically.
  • Automate detection via scripting if dropouts follow a pattern.

docs.title: What You Learned
docs.text:
• Filtering techniques to isolate relevant frames.
  • Measuring signal deviations using cursors and charts.
  • Comparing baseline vs. suspect logs in a single workspace.
  • Preparing evidence for downstream investigations.

docs.title: Next Tutorial
docs.text: Proceed to Injection Scenario Walkthrough to simulate anomalies and validate remedies.

docs.title: System Design Workflow Tutorial
docs.text: This tutorial walks you through designing and deploying a complete ECU system in TrueFidelity, from initial setup to running and monitoring containers.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Goal: Create a multi-ECU system with network connections, configure build settings, deploy containers, and monitor their execution.

Time estimate: 15-20 minutes

Prerequisites: - TrueFidelity installed and activated - Docker Desktop running - ECU firmware binaries available (or use sample builds)

docs.title: Step 1: Create a New System
docs.text:
1. Launch TrueFidelity
  2. Go to File → New (or press Ctrl/Cmd + N)
  1. In the dialog, enter:
  2. System name: tutorial-gateway-system
  3. Save location: Choose your projects folder
  1. Click Create

The System Canvas opens with an empty workspace. The Toolbox panel should be visible on the left.

Note

If the Toolbox isn't visible, open it via View → Panels → Toolbox or press the toolbar button.

docs.title: Step 2: Add ECUs to the Canvas
docs.text:
1. In the Toolbox, locate the ECUs category
  1. Find a Gateway ECU component
  2. Drag it onto the canvas
  1. Repeat to add two more ECUs:
  2. A BCM (Body Control Module)
  3. A PCM (Powertrain Control Module)

Your canvas should now show three ECU nodes. Position them with some space between them.

Tip

Use the canvas zoom controls (mouse wheel or toolbar) to adjust the view. Right-click and drag to pan.

docs.title: Step 3: Configure ECU Properties
docs.text:
1. Click on the Gateway ECU to select it
  1. The Properties Panel (right side) shows ECU configuration
  2. Edit the following properties:
  3. Name: gateway-ecu (or leave default)
  4. Binary path: Browse to your ECU binary file, or leave empty for now
  5. Build target: Select from dropdown (e.g., s32g274a-ubuntu)
  1. Repeat for the BCM and PCM ECUs, giving them distinct names

Note

Binary paths can be set later. For this tutorial, you can proceed without binaries to see the system structure.

docs.title: Step 4: Create Network Connections
docs.text:
1. Click and hold on the Gateway ECU node
  2. Drag a connection line to the BCM ECU
  1. Release to create a network edge
  2. Repeat to connect Gateway to PCM

You should now have two network connections. The edges represent CAN bus or Ethernet links.

docs.title: Step 5: Configure Network Properties
docs.text:
1. Click on a network edge (connection line) to select it
  2. In the Properties Panel, configure:
  3. Network type: Choose CAN or Ethernet
  4. Channel: can0 (or appropriate for your setup)
  5. Baud rate: 500000 (for CAN)
  6. Repeat for the other network edge

docs.title: Step 6: Save the System
docs.text:
1. Press Ctrl/Cmd + S or go to File → Save
  2. Confirm the save location
  3. The system configuration is saved as a .tfsystem file

Your system design is now complete and saved.

docs.title: Step 7: Build Firmware (Optional)
docs.text:
If you have firmware source code:

  1. Select an ECU in the canvas
  2. In Properties, click Build Configuration
  3. Select build target and compiler options
  4. Click Build to compile
  5. Monitor progress in the Build Console panel

For this tutorial, you can skip building if you don't have source code ready.

docs.title: Step 8: Deploy and Start ECUs
docs.text:
1. In the ECU Status panel, you should see your three ECUs listed
  1. Right-click on the Gateway ECU
  2. Select Start from the context menu
  1. Wait for the status to change to "Running" (green indicator)
  1. Repeat for BCM and PCM ECUs

Tip

You can also use the toolbar buttons or keyboard shortcuts to start/stop ECUs. Select multiple ECUs (Ctrl/Cmd + Click) and start them all at once.

docs.title: View ECU Status
docs.text:
1. Open the ECU Status panel (if not already visible)
  2. Verify all three ECUs show "Running" status
  3. Check resource usage columns (CPU%, Memory)

docs.title: View Console Logs
docs.text:
1. Open the Console panel
  2. You should see log messages from all ECUs
  1. Use the filter bar to:
  2. Filter by ECU name (e.g., type gateway)
  3. Filter by log level (toggle info/warn/error/debug)
  4. Search for specific text

docs.title: Monitor Resources
docs.text:
1. Open the Resource Monitor panel
  2. Watch real-time CPU and memory graphs
  3. Each ECU has a colored line on the graph
  4. Adjust the time window using the dropdown (1min, 5min, etc.)

docs.title: View Network Traffic
docs.text:
1. Open the Network Traffic panel
  2. See live CAN messages flowing between ECUs
  3. Filter by message ID, channel, or source ECU
  4. Click any message to see detailed payload

docs.title: Access ECU Terminals
docs.text:
1. Open the Terminal panel
  2. You'll see tabs for each running ECU
  1. Click the gateway-ecu tab
  2. You now have shell access to that ECU's operating system
  3. Try running commands like ls, ps, or cat /proc/meminfo

Warning

Terminal access depends on ECU configuration. Some ECUs may require special setup or have restricted access.

docs.title: Step 10: Make Changes to Running System
Stop an ECU
docs.text:
1. In ECU Status panel, right-click on PCM
  2. Select Stop
  3. Watch the status change to "Stopped"
  4. Console logs will show shutdown messages

docs.title: Restart an ECU
docs.text:
1. Right-click the stopped ECU
  2. Select Start
  3. ECU restarts and logs appear in Console

docs.title: Modify Network Configuration
docs.text:
1. Stop all ECUs (select all, right-click, Stop)
  2. In System Canvas, select a network edge
  3. Change properties (e.g., baud rate)
  4. Save the system
  5. Restart ECUs to apply changes

docs.title: Step 11: Export System Configuration
docs.text:
1. Right-click on the System Canvas
  2. Select Export Configuration
  3. Choose format:
  4. JSON: For programmatic access
  5. YAML: For version control and infrastructure-as-code
  6. Save the file

You can now share this configuration with teammates or use it in automated deployments.

docs.title: Step 12: Cleanup
docs.text:
1. Stop all ECUs (select all in ECU Status, right-click, Stop)
  2. Close the system (File → Close)
  3. Optionally delete the system file if this was just a tutorial

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Explore advanced features in Workspaces & Layouts to save custom panel arrangements
  • Learn about Build Configuration for compiling firmware
  • Read the ECU Monitoring Walkthrough tutorial for deeper monitoring workflows
  • Review Reference → Settings to customize TrueFidelity behavior

docs.title: ECUs won't start
docs.text:
• Verify Docker Desktop is running
  • Check Console panel for error messages
  • Ensure binary paths are correct if specified
  • Try starting one ECU at a time to isolate issues

docs.title: Terminal connection fails
docs.text:
• Verify ECU is running (green status in ECU Status panel)
  • Check that terminal service is enabled in ECU configuration
  • Review Console logs for connection errors
  • Some ECU images may not have terminal support enabled

docs.title: Network traffic not appearing
docs.text:
• Ensure network edges are properly configured
  • Verify ECU firmware is sending CAN messages
  • Check Network Traffic panel filters aren't hiding messages
  • Confirm network type matches ECU configuration

docs.title: Annotations & Bookmarks
docs.text: Annotations and bookmarks capture insights while you analyze playback. They add structure to reports, help teams collaborate, and make exporting findings quick.

docs.title: Annotations vs. Bookmarks
docs.text:
• Bookmark: Quick marker with a title and timestamp. Ideal for rapid flagging.
  • Annotation: Expanded note with description, tags, severity, attachments, and linked segments.
  • Both appear on the timeline as markers and in the Annotations panel for navigation.

docs.title: Creating Annotations
docs.text:
1. Pause playback at the moment of interest.
  2. Press A or click the Add Annotation button in the Annotations panel.
  3. Fill in the details:
  4. Title – Keep concise but descriptive.
  5. Description – Provide context, observed behavior, expected behavior, and next steps.
  6. Tags – Add keywords like safety, powertrain, regression.
  7. Severity – Optional field if your build includes severity levels.
  8. Attachments – Link to external documents or evidence, stored relative to the project.
  9. Click Save. The annotation now appears in the list and on the timeline.

Tip

Use copy/paste for annotations to duplicate structure across similar events—handy when logging repeated occurrences.

docs.title: Bookmark Workflow
docs.text:
• Press B to drop a bookmark at the current time.
  • Rename directly in the timeline or in the Annotations panel.
  • Upgrade a bookmark to a full annotation later by adding description and tags.

docs.title: Sorting & Filtering
docs.text:
• Sort by timestamp, title, severity, or tag.
  • Filter by tag to focus on specific themes (e.g., noise, CAN-error).
  • Combine filters with timeline ranges to review annotations within a particular segment.

docs.title: Editing & Deleting
docs.text:
• Select an annotation and click Edit to update fields.
  • Use Duplicate to create a copy at the same timestamp (change the tags to differentiate).
  • Delete with Del or the context menu (action is reversible via undo until you close the project).

docs.title: Linking to Segments
docs.text:
• With a range selected, open an annotation and choose Link to current segment. This ties the note to that exact duration for exports.
  • Multiple annotations can link to the same segment—ideal for collaborative reviews.

docs.title: Annotation Templates
docs.text:
1. Navigate to Annotations → Templates.
  2. Create templates for recurring issues (e.g., “Spike detected”, “CAN timeout”).
  3. Predefine tags, severity, and description prompts.
  4. When adding a new annotation, choose a template to prefill fields. Customize as needed before saving.

docs.title: Exporting Annotations
docs.text:
• CSV Export: Click Export → CSV to generate a spreadsheet including timestamp, title, tags, and description.
  • Report Builder: Add selected annotations to the report queue. The builder inserts them into summary tables and narrative sections.
  • Screenshot integration: Use the screenshot button within the annotation to capture the current chart or panel view; the image links to the annotation.

docs.title: Collaboration Tips
docs.text:
• Assign tags to identify the author (tag:alice).
  • Use severity levels (critical, major, minor) to prioritize follow-up work.
  • Include links to issue trackers in the description for traceability.
  • Hold review sessions by filtering annotations to a specific tag (e.g., ready-for-review).

docs.title: Keyboard Shortcuts
docs.text: Action Shortcut Add annotation A Add bookmark B Toggle Annotations panel Ctrl/Cmd + 6 (configurable) Jump to next/previous annotation Alt + ↓ / Alt + ↑ Filter annotations by current tag Ctrl/Cmd + Shift + T

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text: Issue Fix Annotations missing after reopen Ensure autosave completed or manually save the project before closing. Tags inconsistent Establish a tag naming convention and share it in team documentation. Export missing screenshots Ensure screenshots were saved to a path accessible relative to the project before exporting. Timeline cluttered Hide annotation markers temporarily via the timeline options menu.

docs.title: Integrating With Reports
docs.text:
• Use Report Builder to include annotation tables automatically.
  • Add context paragraphs to the description field; they appear verbatim in the report.
  • Attach charts or links to rerun scripts to support each annotation’s findings.

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Learn to combine annotations with filtered playback in Playback and Filters & Search.
  • Explore Exports & Reports to turn annotations into polished deliverables.
  • Consult Glossary for definitions of fields referenced in annotation dialogs.

docs.title: Controls & Panels
docs.text:
Understanding each panel and control allows you to tailor TrueFidelity to your workflow. This guide describes panel functionality, configuration options, and best practices.

Panels are organized by workflow: System Design, ECU Monitoring, and CAN Log Analysis. Most panels are dockable and can be rearranged to match your preferred layout.

docs.title: System Canvas
docs.text:
• Drag-and-drop: Add ECUs from the Toolbox by dragging onto the canvas
  • Network connections: Click and drag between ECUs to create network edges
  • Multi-select: Hold Ctrl/Cmd and click multiple elements, or drag a selection box
  • Zoom controls: Mouse wheel to zoom, or use toolbar buttons
  • Pan: Middle-click and drag, or spacebar + drag
  • Export: Right-click canvas to export system configuration

Tip

Use the grid snap feature (View → Snap to Grid) to keep your layouts clean and organized.

docs.title: Toolbox
docs.text:
• Categories: Browse ECU types, network interfaces, and gateway components
  • Search: Type to filter available components
  • Drag to add: Drag any component from Toolbox to Canvas to instantiate
  • Templates: Save custom ECU configurations as templates for reuse

docs.title: Properties Panel
docs.text:
• Context-aware: Shows properties for the currently selected element (ECU, network, edge)
  • Editable fields: Click any property value to edit directly
  • Validation: Invalid values are highlighted with error indicators
  • Presets: Save property configurations as presets

docs.title: Project Explorer
docs.text:
• File tree: Navigate system files, builds, and configurations
  • Context menu: Right-click for options (open, delete, rename)
  • Favorites: Pin frequently accessed files for quick access
  • Search: Use Ctrl/Cmd + F to search within the explorer

docs.title: ECU Status Panel
docs.text:
• Grid view: All ECUs displayed in a sortable table
  • Status indicators: Color-coded states (green=running, yellow=starting, red=error, gray=stopped)
  • Quick actions: Right-click any ECU for context menu (start, stop, restart, logs)
  • Resource summary: Hover over resource cells to see detailed metrics
  • Double-click: Open ECU detail view in new panel

docs.title: Console Panel
docs.text:
• Unified logs: Aggregated output from all ECUs in one view
  • Filter bar: Filter by ECU name, log level, or search term
  • Log levels: Toggle visibility of info, warn, error, debug messages
  • Color coding: Log levels are color-coded for quick scanning
  • Auto-scroll: Toggle to keep view locked to latest messages
  • Export: Export filtered logs to text file

Tip

Use the pause button to freeze the log view while investigating a specific message, then resume auto-scroll.

docs.title: Resource Monitor
docs.text:
• Real-time graphs: Live CPU and memory usage over time
  • Per-ECU metrics: Separate lines for each ECU with color coding
  • Time range: Adjust visible time window (1min, 5min, 15min, 1hr)
  • Zoom: Click and drag on graph to zoom into specific time ranges
  • Export: Export metrics as CSV for analysis or PNG for reports

docs.title: Network Traffic Panel
docs.text:
• Live monitoring: Real-time CAN message stream
  • Filters: Filter by message ID (hex or decimal), channel, or source ECU
  • Message details: Click any message to see payload, timestamp, flags
  • Rate statistics: View messages per second and total counts
  • Export: Capture traffic to log file (BLF, MDF4, CSV)
  • DBC integration: Signals are decoded when DBC files are loaded

docs.title: Terminal Panel
docs.text:
• Multi-tab interface: One terminal tab per ECU
  • Full shell access: Interactive terminal to ECU operating system
  • Connection status: Visual indicators show connection state
  • Search: Press Ctrl+F to search terminal output
  • Terminal actions: Clear screen, copy selection, reconnect
  • Resize handling: Terminal automatically adjusts to panel size

Warning

Terminal access requires appropriate permissions. Some ECUs may restrict root access or certain commands.

docs.title: Process Monitor
docs.text:
• Process list: View all running processes within selected ECU
  • Resource usage: CPU and memory per process
  • Process tree: Expandable tree view showing parent-child relationships
  • Sortable columns: Click column headers to sort
  • Refresh rate: Adjust update frequency in panel settings

docs.title: Signals Panel
docs.text:
• Search: Filter by name, ID, unit, or tags. Partial matches supported.
  • Pinned signals: Click the pin icon to add to the watch list; pinned signals persist across sessions.
  • Context menu: Right-click a signal to add to charts, copy name, or highlight in Messages.
  • Grouping: Use tags or DBC categories to sort signals. Toggle groups in the left-hand tree.
  • Derived signals: If configured, derived entries appear with a calculator icon.

docs.title: Messages Panel
docs.text:
• Columns: Timestamp, ID, DLC, payload, channel, flags. Choose Columns from the toolbar to show/hide fields.
  • Freeze scroll: Lock the view while playback continues—useful for inspecting a burst without losing context.
  • Color rules: Apply highlight rules to emphasize frames matching filters (e.g., error flags).
  • Export: Use Export Visible to write a CSV of the filtered dataset.

docs.title: Charts Panel
docs.text:
• Add signals: Drag from the Signals panel or use the + button inside Charts.
  • Axes: Right-click to split signals across multiple Y-axes or lock them to a shared scale.
  • Cursors: Press Shift + C to add cursors; the delta time and value difference show in the legend.
  • Legends: Toggle series visibility; double-click a legend entry to isolate a signal temporarily.
  • Screenshots: Capture a PNG directly from the toolbar; stored in your export folder.

docs.title: Timeline
docs.text:
• Selection: Drag to select; double-click to reset.
  • Markers: Bookmark and annotation markers appear; click to open details.
  • Named segments: Right-click and save selections with descriptive names for reuse.
  • Zoom: Scroll wheel zooms; Shift + wheel pans. Keyboard = and - also zoom.

docs.title: Annotations Panel
docs.text:
• Lists bookmarks and annotations chronologically.
  • Filter by tags, severity, or author.
  • Export as CSV or send to Report Builder.
  • Templates accelerate repetitive annotation entry.

docs.title: Data Injection Panel
docs.text:
• Message list: Shows defined templates with ID, payload, schedule, status.
  • Schedule editor: Configure once, interval, burst, or ramp profiles.
  • Counters: Track sent/failed frames, rate, and elapsed time.
  • Profiles: Save multiple injection scenarios; export/import for consistency across test stations.

docs.title: Watch List
docs.text:
• Pinned signals appear here for quick reference.
  • Drag watch entries to Charts to plot or to Annotations to insert current values into notes.
  • Reorder using drag-and-drop to keep key signals on top.

docs.title: Filters Panel
docs.text:
• Manage saved filters and filter sets.
  • Toggle filters on/off without deleting them.
  • See active filters at a glance; apply them to Messages, Charts, or both.

docs.title: Export Queue
docs.text:
• View and manage pending exports.
  • Reorder, pause, or delete queued tasks.
  • Useful when batch exporting multiple segments overnight.

docs.title: Reports Panel
docs.text:
• Launch Report Builder.
  • Assemble annotations, charts, statistics, and screenshots into PDF/HTML packages.
  • Preview report sections before exporting.

docs.title: Properties/Inspector Panel
docs.text:
• Shows metadata for the selected item (frame, signal, annotation, export task).
  • Edit description, tags, or destination paths directly.
  • Displays derived values such as scaling and raw hex.

docs.title: Layout Controls
docs.text:
• Docking handles appear when dragging panel tabs.
  • Split view icons split panels vertically or horizontally (in some builds).
  • Reset layout returns everything to defaults; use saved layouts to restore custom arrangements.

docs.title: Panel Shortcuts
docs.text:
Panel Shortcut (default) Context ECU Status / Signals Ctrl/Cmd + 1 Monitoring / Analysis Console / Messages Ctrl/Cmd + 2 Monitoring / Analysis Resource Monitor / Charts Ctrl/Cmd + 3 Monitoring / Analysis Terminal / Data Injection Ctrl/Cmd + 4 Monitoring / Analysis Annotations Ctrl/Cmd + 5 Analysis Filters Ctrl/Cmd + 6 Analysis Project Explorer Ctrl/Cmd + B All modes System Canvas Ctrl/Cmd + Shift + C Design Properties Ctrl/Cmd + Shift + P All modes

Customize these shortcuts under Settings → Shortcuts to align with your preferences. Some shortcuts are context-dependent and switch functionality based on the active workflow mode.

docs.title: Panel Tips
docs.text:
• Focus mode: Double-click a panel tab to expand it to full screen; double-click again to restore.
  • Linked selections: Enable linked selection between Messages and Charts so selecting a frame highlights corresponding signal values.
  • Panel presets: Save panel configurations (e.g., chart axis settings) as presets to reapply later.

docs.title: Troubleshooting Panels
docs.text: Problem Solution Panel missing Check if it’s minimized or tabbed behind another panel. Use View menu to reopen. Panel flickers Disable hardware acceleration via launch flag or update GPU drivers. Panel content blank Reset layout; ensure filters aren’t hiding all data. Dragging unintentionally undocks panels Hold Alt while dragging to prevent undocking, or adjust drag thresholds in settings.

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Move to Exports & Reports to learn how to package results.
  • Review Shortcuts to speed up navigation between panels.
  • Combine panel arrangements with Workspaces & Layouts for repeatable workflows.

docs.title: DBC & Signal Definitions
docs.text: Signal definitions translate raw CAN payloads into human-readable values. TrueFidelity supports DBC and other metadata files so you can analyze signals with units, scaling, and diagnostics. This page explains how to import, manage, and troubleshoot definitions.

docs.title: Supported Formats
docs.text:
• DBC – Common CAN database format containing message and signal definitions.
  • ARXML (read-only support depending on your build).
  • JSON/custom mapping files if provided by your organization.

Consult release notes for additional supported formats in your distribution.

docs.title: Importing Definitions
docs.text:
1. Open your project in TrueFidelity.
  2. Choose Project → Import Definitions.
  3. Select one or more DBC files.
  4. Confirm the import summary—messages, signals, and comments are listed.
  5. Definitions appear under Definitions in the sidebar.

Tip

Store DBC files inside your project directory or in a shared network location. Relative paths keep projects portable across machines.

docs.title: Definition Priority
docs.text:
When multiple files define the same message or signal:

  • Open the Definitions panel.
  • Drag definitions to reorder them. Higher entries take precedence.
  • Use the conflict indicator (exclamation mark) to review overlapping signals.
  • Disable a definition temporarily via the checkbox for testing.

docs.title: Syncing Definitions With Projects
docs.text:
• Definitions are referenced by path. If the file moves, you’ll see a warning in the Definitions panel.
  • Click Locate to update the path.
  • Use Project → Export Definitions to package all referenced files for teammates.

docs.title: Signal Metadata
docs.text:
• Signals inherit their name, unit, scaling, offset, min/max, and comments from the definition.
  • Tooltips show this metadata in the Signals panel and Charts legend.
  • If definitions include categories or tags, they become search filters in the Signals panel.

docs.title: Editing Definitions
docs.text:
TrueFidelity does not modify DBC files directly. To edit definitions:

  1. Open the DBC in your preferred editor (e.g., Vector CANdb++, open-source editors).
  2. Adjust messages or signals.
  3. Save the DBC.
  4. Back in TrueFidelity, click Reload in the Definitions panel to pick up changes.

docs.title: Derived Signals and Formulas
docs.text:
• Some releases support derived signals using mathematical expressions.
  • Configure derived signals via Project → Manage Derived Signals.
  • Derived signals appear alongside decoded signals and follow the same pinning/export rules.

docs.title: Diagnostic Dictionaries
docs.text:
• Import diagnostic mapping files (if available) to decode UDS/KWP responses.
  • Diagnostics view uses these dictionaries to label service IDs and parameter values.

docs.title: Troubleshooting Definitions
docs.text: Issue Suggested Action Signals show raw hex instead of values Ensure the correct DBC is imported and prioritized. Check that the message ID matches the bus (standard vs. extended). Units incorrect Verify the DBC scaling; if the definition is outdated, request the latest version from your calibration team. DBC file missing after clone Confirm relative paths; store definitions inside the project or update the path using Locate. Newly added signals not visible Reload definitions or restart the application to clear cached metadata. Conflicting definitions Reorder or disable alternate DBC files until the intended signals decode correctly.

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
• Version-control your DBC files; include version numbers in filenames (Powertrain_v2025.dbc).
  • Maintain a change log so engineers know what signals were added or altered.
  • Bundle DBC files with projects when sharing externally to preserve decoding fidelity.
  • Use tags within DBC comments to drive signal grouping (e.g., [category=brakes]).

docs.title: Automation & Validation
docs.text:
• Scripts can compare DBC versions by exporting signal lists from TrueFidelity (Project → Export Definition Summary).
  • When updating firmware, load both old and new DBC files and use the priority system to validate differences.

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Proceed to Controls & Panels to work with decoded signals in charts and watch lists.
  • Review Exports & Reports to include decoded values in deliverables.
  • Keep Glossary handy for terminology used in definitions dialogs.

docs.title: Exports & Reports
docs.text: TrueFidelity offers flexible export options so you can share findings with teammates, customers, or automated pipelines. This guide covers segment exports, message exports, report builder usage, and best practices.

docs.title: Export Types Overview
docs.text: Export Description Typical Use Segment Export Exports selected timeline range to CSV, MDF4, or other supported formats. Share subsets of data without releasing full logs. Message Export Exports filtered frames from the Messages panel. Provide raw data for downstream tools. Screenshot Captures the current chart or panel as PNG. Include visuals in presentations or reports. Annotation CSV List of annotations/bookmarks with timestamps and tags. Review session notes, build test case documentation. Report Builder Generates PDF/HTML summary with charts, annotations, statistics, and attachments. Formal documentation for design reviews or audits.

docs.title: Segment Export Workflow
docs.text:
1. Select a range on the timeline.
  2. Verify filters are applied as desired (Filter-to-Range, message filters).
  3. Click File → Export Segment or use the toolbar button.
  4. Choose format:
  5. CSV: Wide table of timestamp, ID, payload, decoded signals.
  6. MDF4/BLF: Maintains binary format for compatibility with other CAN tools.
  7. JSON (optional): Structured export if your build supports it.
  8. Configure options:
  9. Include annotations within the range.
  10. Include decoded signals or raw payload only.
  11. Choose delimiter and decimal precision for CSV.
  12. Set destination filename and folder.
  13. Click Export. Monitor progress in the Export Queue.

Tip

Name exports using YYYY-MM-DD_project_signal_range to keep them sorted chronologically and contextually.

docs.title: Message Export
docs.text:
• Apply filters in the Messages panel to isolate data.
  • Click Export → Visible Rows.
  • Choose CSV or binary format depending on downstream needs.
  • Saved filters ensure exports remain consistent across iterations.

docs.title: Annotation Export
docs.text:
• Open the Annotations panel.
  • Filter by tags (e.g., safety or testday-05).
  • Click Export → CSV.
  • The CSV includes timestamp, tag, description, and linked segment info.

docs.title: Screenshot Export
docs.text:
• Use the camera icon in Charts or the toolbar to capture the current view.
  • Screenshots are saved to the export folder by default.
  • Naming includes timestamp; rename to match the associated annotation or report section.

docs.title: Report Builder
docs.text:
Report Builder packages your analysis into a polished deliverable.

  1. Open Reports panel and click New Report.
  2. Select a template (e.g., Validation, Regression Summary). Templates define cover pages, sections, and branding.
  3. Add content:
  4. Overview – Enter summary text, objectives, and test context.
  5. Annotations – Choose which annotations to include; they populate tables with time, tags, and notes.
  6. Charts – Attach live charts or imported screenshots. For live charts, specify the signals and time ranges to render.
  7. Key Metrics – Import statistics from performance panels (message rates, peaks, etc.).
  8. Attachments – Include links to exported segments or external documents.
  9. Preview the report in the right-hand pane.
  10. Export to PDF or HTML. PDF is ideal for signing/archiving; HTML works for web-based portals.

docs.title: Customizing Templates
docs.text:
• Navigate to Reports → Manage Templates.
  • Clone an existing template and edit branding, section order, and default text.
  • Share template files with teammates so everyone produces consistent reports.

docs.title: Export Queue Management
docs.text:
• Open the Export Queue panel to view active exports.
  • Reorder tasks to prioritize urgent exports.
  • Pause/resume or delete queued tasks as needed.
  • Export logs record success/failure messages; review them if an export fails.

docs.title: Automation Hooks
docs.text:
• Some deployments include CLI tools: truefidelity-cli export --project file.tfproj --range 0-60s --format csv.
  • Schedule exports overnight via OS task schedulers or CI pipelines using these CLI utilities.
  • Combine automation with version-controlled projects to deliver reproducible export bundles.

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
• Use consistent naming conventions and include ticket IDs or experiment numbers in filenames.
  • Store exports alongside the originating project to preserve context.
  • Keep a README with exports describing their purpose, filters, and responsible engineer.
  • For long sessions, export multiple shorter segments instead of a single large file to simplify review.

docs.title: Troubleshooting Exports
docs.text: Issue Suggested Fix Export queue stuck Check that the destination drive has free space; resume or restart the export queue. CSV columns misaligned Verify delimiter and line ending options. Use UTF-8 encoding for international characters. Report missing images Ensure screenshots remained in place when exporting; relative paths should be inside the project folder. Exported data empty Confirm range selection contains data and filters are not excluding everything.

docs.title: Compliance & Traceability
docs.text:
• Include hash values of exported files in audit logs (compute via OS tools) when compliance requires verification.
  • Store report PDFs in document management systems with version history.
  • Attach exported segments and reports to issue tracking tickets for test evidence.

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Explore Performance Tips to tune system resources before large exports.
  • Continue to Tutorials for end-to-end scenarios that culminate in deliverables.
  • Review Support to learn where to send exports when requesting assistance.

docs.title: Filters & Search
docs.text: Filtering and searching allow you to isolate critical frames, signals, and time windows quickly. This guide covers message filters, signal search, saved queries, and best practices for building reusable filters.

docs.title: Quick Filters
docs.text:
• ID filter: Enter numeric IDs in hex (0x123) or decimal (291). Use comma-separated lists for multiple IDs.
  • Payload search: Type a hex sequence (AA FF) to match payload segments. Wildcards (??) match any nibble.
  • Channel filter: Choose specific channels (e.g., can0) using the channel dropdown.
  • Time range: Use the time slider or enter start/end times to focus on a segment.

docs.title: Advanced Filter Builder
docs.text:
1. Click the Filter button in the Messages toolbar.
  2. Build conditions using AND/OR groups.
  3. Available fields: ID, DLC, Payload, Channel, Timestamp, Flags, Signal values (when decoded).
  4. Save the filter with a descriptive name (e.g., Safety_Critical_IDs).

Example filter:

(ID == 0x123 OR ID == 0x456) AND Payload starts with AA AND Timestamp between 10s and 60s

Saved filters appear in the dropdown for one-click reuse.

docs.title: Signal Search & Watch Lists
docs.text:
• Open the Signals panel and use the search box to find signals by name, unit, or DBC comment.
  • Filter by source definition file to reduce results when multiple DBCs overlap.
  • Pin signals to add them to the watch list; pinned signals stay visible across sessions.
  • Use tags (configured in your definitions) to group signals (e.g., powertrain, braking).

Tip

When searching for diagnostic PIDs, prefix with 0x to match exactly; otherwise partial text search returns broader results.

docs.title: Timeline Search
docs.text:
• Press Ctrl/Cmd + F to open the timeline search bar.
  • Enter a timestamp (00:10:25.500) or relative offset (+5s, -3s) to jump the playhead.
  • Search for annotations by title/tag (e.g., tag:spike).

docs.title: Global Search (Command Palette)
docs.text:
• Press Ctrl/Cmd + P.
  • Type commands (export segment, add annotation), panel names (charts, signals), or documentation topics (data injection).
  • Use arrow keys to select results and press Enter to execute.

docs.title: Combining Filters with Timeline Ranges
docs.text:
1. Select a range on the timeline.
  2. Enable Filter to Range (toolbar icon or Ctrl/Cmd + Shift + F).
  3. Apply message filters to focus on IDs or payloads within that range.
  4. Charts and statistics update instantly based on the filtered data.

docs.title: Saved Filter Sets
docs.text:
• Use Filter Sets to bundle multiple filters (ID + payload + time) into a single preset.
  • Apply a filter set with one click from the toolbar.
  • Export/import filter sets (*.tffilter) to share with colleagues.

docs.title: Highlighting Frames
docs.text:
• Enable Highlight rules in the Messages panel to color frames that match certain conditions (e.g., errors, thresholds).
  • Configure the rule color, criteria, and optional sound alert.

docs.title: Search in Exports
docs.text:
• When exporting CSV, enable Include filters in metadata so recipients know which criteria were used.
  • Report Builder automatically lists active filters in the summary page.

docs.title: Diagnostics for Filters
docs.text:
• Use the Filter Inspector (View → Filter Inspector) to see which filters are active across panels.
  • Temporarily disable a filter via the toggle next to its name to compare results quickly.

docs.title: Managing Performance
docs.text:
• Avoid stacking too many complex OR conditions; break them into separate filters and apply sequentially.
  • Use numeric comparisons (>, <, between) instead of large ID lists when possible.
  • For enormous datasets, apply filters before enabling heavy visualizations.

docs.title: Locate Brake Events
docs.text:
1. Filter IDs to known brake-related frames.
  2. Apply payload rule for the bit indicating brake pedal pressed.
  3. Filter time range to 0–300 s.
  4. Add annotation template (Brake Event) for quick tagging.

docs.title: Isolate Fault Codes
docs.text:
1. Search signals for DTC or fault.
  2. Pin relevant signals and add them to Charts.
  3. Create a filter for payload patterns that correspond to diagnostic trouble codes.
  4. Export only frames matching the payload filter.

docs.title: Validate New Firmware
docs.text:
1. Load baseline and new firmware logs.
  2. Apply the same filter set to both sessions.
  3. Use charts to compare key signals; highlight mismatched ranges with annotations.

docs.title: Keyboard Shortcuts
docs.text: Action Shortcut Toggle Messages filter bar Ctrl/Cmd + F Clear all filters Ctrl/Cmd + Shift + C Focus global search Ctrl/Cmd + P Add current filter to set Ctrl/Cmd + Shift + S

docs.title: Troubleshooting Filters
docs.text: Symptom Fix Filter returns no frames Relax conditions or check for inverted comparisons (e.g., < vs <=). Filters reset after restart Ensure you saved the filter; autosave must be enabled or manually save the project. Performance slows dramatically Combine filters or simplify payload rules; consider limiting to a smaller range. Filters not applied to charts Ensure Filter to Range is active or add the filter directly in the Charts panel’s data source settings.

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Continue to Annotations & Bookmarks to learn how to document findings.
  • Read Exports & Reports to create deliverables based on filtered data.
  • Explore Glossary if you encounter unfamiliar terms within filter dialogs.

docs.title: Playback
docs.text: Playback is the heart of TrueFidelity. This guide details timeline navigation, transport controls, range selection, smart filtering, and tips for handling large log files.

docs.title: Transport Controls
docs.text:
• Play/Pause (Space) – Start or stop playback.
  • Step Forward/Backward (→/←) – Move one frame at a time. Hold Shift to jump one second.
  • Jump to Start/End (Home/End) – Quickly reset to the beginning or skip to the end.
  • Speed Selector – Choose from 0.25×, 0.5×, 1×, 2×, 4×, 8×. Speeds above 4× rely on your system’s I/O performance.
  • Loop Toggle – When enabled, the selected range repeats until you disable it.
  • Sync Playheads – If multiple charts are open, enabling sync keeps all charts aligned with the timeline.

Tip

Assign custom shortcuts to common speeds (e.g., 1×, 2×, 0.25×) under Settings → Shortcuts.

docs.title: Timeline Navigation
docs.text:
• Click the timeline to move the playhead instantly.
  • Drag to select a range. The status bar shows start, end, and duration.
  • Scroll wheel zooms in/out of the cursor position. Hold Ctrl/Cmd while scrolling for slower zooming.
  • Shift + Scroll pans left/right without changing zoom.
  • Double-click the timeline background to reset zoom to full duration.
  • Markers appear for annotations, bookmarks, or injection events. Hover to see tooltips.

docs.title: Range Selection Workflows
docs.text:
• To focus on an event, drag to highlight a range and enable Filter to Range (toolbar button). Messages, charts, and statistics now show only data inside the selection.
  • Use Loop to replay the selected range while adjusting filters or annotations.
  • Right-click the range to save it as a named segment (e.g., ABS Event 1). Named segments help with quick navigation and exports.

docs.title: Messages View Sync
docs.text:
• Messages automatically scroll to match the current timeline position.
  • Apply filters (ID, payload, channel, time window) to reduce noise.
  • Freeze Scroll to examine a section while playback continues. When ready, unfreeze to re-sync.

docs.title: Charts & Signals During Playback
docs.text:
• Pinned signals appear in the chart. Drag additional signals to compare behavior.
  • Use Auto-scale for exploratory work and Fixed scale when producing reports for consistent axes.
  • Add Cursors (Shift + C) to measure time differences between two points. The delta displays in the chart legend.
  • Toggle series visibility using the legend to isolate signals temporarily.

docs.title: Annotations & Bookmarks
docs.text:
• Press A to create an annotation at the current playhead. Add tags, descriptions, and severity (if configured).
  • Use Bookmarks (B) for quick markers without extra metadata.
  • Annotated points show directly on the timeline; clicking an annotation jumps to the location and opens details in the right-hand panel.

docs.title: Counters & Diagnostics
docs.text:
• Messages/sec – Real-time throughput for the current view. High values indicate denser sections of the log.
  • Dropped frames – Highlights hardware or decoding bottlenecks. Investigate when non-zero.
  • CPU/IO gauges – Optional overlay showing resource usage; enable in Settings → Diagnostics.

docs.title: Handling Large Logs
docs.text:
• Load only the logs you need for a session. Remove others using the project explorer context menu.
  • Use Filter-to-Range and message filters to avoid rendering millions of frames at once.
  • Reduce chart complexity—combine signals into fewer charts when possible.
  • Store logs on SSDs or NVMe drives to avoid I/O bottlenecks.
  • Enable Incremental Decoding (Settings → Data) to decode as you scrub, reducing initial load times.

docs.title: Working with Multiple Logs
docs.text:
• Enable Multi-log mode to overlay multiple runs. Each log displays with a different color band on the timeline.
  • Use Align by Timestamp or Align by Offset options to synchronize logs.
  • Mute individual logs temporarily using checkboxes in the project explorer.

docs.title: Playback for Live Streams
docs.text:
If your deployment supports live capture:

  • Use the same controls; the timeline shows a trailing buffer for live data.
  • Loop mode is disabled while live streaming; manual range selection still works for captured segments.
  • Annotations are supported; they bind to the recorded timestamp once data is flushed to disk.

docs.title: Exporting from Playback
docs.text:
• Export Segment – Uses the currently selected range. Choose format (CSV, MDF4) and destination.
  • Screenshot – Use the camera icon in Charts or the Annotations panel to capture context.
  • Report Builder – While paused, launch the builder to queue charts, annotations, and notes into a report template.

docs.title: Keyboard Shortcut Reference
docs.text: Action Shortcut Play/Pause Space Step forward/backward → / ← Jump ±5 seconds Shift + → / Shift + ← Jump to start/end Home / End Toggle loop L Add annotation A Add bookmark B Toggle filter-to-range Ctrl/Cmd + Shift + F Zoom in/out = / - (or mouse wheel)

docs.title: Troubleshooting Playback
docs.text: Problem Suggested Fix Playback stutters Reduce speed, close unused panels, move logs to faster storage. Charts lag behind Limit to critical signals, disable auto-scale, or increase chart buffer in Settings → Charts. Time jumps unexpectedly Check for large gaps or overlapping timestamps; use Normalize timestamps option in the timeline menu. No audio cues Some builds include optional audio alerts; enable under Settings → Accessibility.

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
• Use consistent naming for annotations and segments to streamline reporting.
  • Pair playback with filters; start broad, then refine as you zero in on anomalies.
  • Save snapshots of critical ranges so you can return during reviews without rescanning the timeline.

docs.title: Related Documentation
docs.text:
• Filters & Search – For advanced filtering strategies.
  • Annotations & Bookmarks – To organize findings during playback.
  • Exports & Reports – To share playback insights with stakeholders.

docs.title: Projects & Files
docs.text: Projects keep all your work organized—logs, definitions, filters, layouts, and exports. This guide explains how to create, manage, and collaborate on projects without touching internal implementation details.

docs.title: Creating Projects
docs.text:
1. Launch TrueFidelity.
  2. Select File → New Project.
  3. Name the project (avoid spaces if you plan to sync with automation scripts).
  4. Choose a location on fast local storage.
  5. Click Create. The project is added to the sidebar and saved as a .tfproj file.

Tip

Store projects in a version-controlled folder (e.g., Git or your document management system) to track changes and collaborate safely.

docs.title: Opening Projects
docs.text:
• Recent projects: Use File → Recent Projects to open the last ten items.
  • Browse: Choose File → Open Project and select a .tfproj file.
  • Drag & drop: Drop a .tfproj file into the TrueFidelity window.

When a project opens, its layout, pinned signals, filters, and file references restore automatically.

docs.title: Adding Log Files
docs.text:
• Click + Add Files in the sidebar or use File → Open.
  • Select one or more log files. Each is referenced in the project without being copied (unless you enable file copy in Settings → Data).
  • Logs appear under the project’s Files section. Right-click to rename the display label, reveal in the OS, or remove from the project.

docs.title: File Copy Options
docs.text:
• Link (default): The project stores absolute paths. If you move the source file, update the link.
  • Copy into project folder: Enable in Settings → Data → Copy imported files. Great for portable projects but uses more disk space.

docs.title: Organizing Files
docs.text:
• Use subfolders inside your project directory to store exports, screenshots, and documents. The project references them via relative paths.
  • Rename imported files in the project explorer to add context (display name only; the original file is untouched).
  • Tag logs with metadata using the Properties panel—add notes such as vehicle, test track, or firmware version.

docs.title: Importing Definitions
docs.text:
1. Click Project → Import Definitions.
  2. Select DBC or other supported definition files.
  3. Define priority order when multiple definitions overlap.
  4. The imported files appear under Definitions in the sidebar.

Definitions are stored relative to the project. If you share a project, include the definitions directory or use shared network paths.

docs.title: Project Autosave
docs.text:
• Projects autosave periodically. Configure frequency under Settings → General.
  • Manual save remains available via File → Save Project (Ctrl/Cmd + S).
  • Autosave writes to the same .tfproj file; consider version control or snapshots to preserve milestones.

docs.title: Working with Multiple Logs
docs.text:
• Load multiple log files into a single project for comparisons.
  • Use Multi-file timeline mode to align logs by timestamp or relative offset.
  • Group logs into scenarios (e.g., Baseline, Modified, Regression) and enable/disable them using checkboxes in the sidebar.

docs.title: Project Templates
docs.text:
• Configure a project with preferred layouts, pinned signals, filters, and definitions.
  • Save a copy as Template-[purpose].tfproj.
  • When starting new work, duplicate the template and rename it—instant consistency.

docs.title: Collaboration and Sharing
docs.text:
• Store projects in shared drives or version control repositories.
  • To send a project via email, zip the .tfproj file plus referenced logs/definitions (use relative paths to simplify).
  • Include a README within the project folder describing purpose, dataset versions, and any custom scripts.

Warning

Avoid editing the same project simultaneously from multiple machines without coordination. Conflicting writes can corrupt the .tfproj file.

docs.title: Backups and Archiving
docs.text:
• Use File → Export Project Summary to capture a manifest of files, definitions, and versions.
  • Snapshot projects before major changes using OS-level copy commands or backup tools.
  • Archive finished projects in compressed form to save disk space while retaining reproducibility.

docs.title: Cleaning Up Projects
docs.text:
• Remove unused log references via right-click → Remove. This action does not delete the actual file unless you choose Delete from disk.
  • Use Project → Manage Files to list dangling references (files moved or deleted outside the app).

docs.title: Integrating with Automation
docs.text:
• Command-line tools (if provided by your distribution) can open projects with flags for batch exports.
  • Store automation scripts alongside projects so teammates can replicate results.

docs.title: Troubleshooting Project Issues
docs.text: Issue Solution Project fails to open Check if the .tfproj file is read-only or corrupted; restore from backup if necessary. File path missing Use the Locate button in the Properties panel to update the path to the relocated log. Definitions not applied Confirm the definition file is still reachable and appears in the Definitions list; re-import if moved. Autosave conflicts Disable autosave temporarily or coordinate with team members to avoid editing the same project across remote sessions.

docs.text:
• Continue to Playback to learn timeline controls.
  • Visit Filters & Search for message and signal filtering techniques.
  • Explore Exports & Reports to share project results with stakeholders.

docs.title: Customizing Shortcuts
docs.text:
1. Open Settings → Shortcuts.
  2. Locate the command you want to modify.
  3. Click the shortcut field and press the new key combination.
  4. Conflicts are highlighted; resolve by choosing a unique combination.
  5. Export or import shortcut profiles to share with teammates.

Tip

Build shortcut presets for specific roles (e.g., test engineer vs. data analyst). Store preset files alongside project templates.

docs.title: Accessibility Considerations
docs.text:
• Enable High-contrast keyboard focus in Settings → Accessibility if you need clearer focus indicators.
  • For one-handed operation, map frequent actions to function keys (F1–F12).
  • If you use a programmable keypad, bind macros to multi-step tasks (play + annotate, filter + export, etc.).

docs.title: Troubleshooting Shortcut Issues
docs.text: Problem Solution Shortcut not working Check for conflicts or OS-level overrides (e.g., macOS Mission Control using Ctrl + Arrow). Shortcut resets after restart Ensure you saved the shortcut profile; autosave must be enabled or manually press Save in the shortcut dialog. External keyboard behaves differently Confirm layout settings (ANSI vs. ISO) and adjust key mappings accordingly. Need to revert to defaults Click Restore Defaults in the shortcut settings and restart TrueFidelity.
