docs.title: UI Tour
docs.text: This tour introduces every major area of the TrueFidelity interface so you can navigate confidently before diving into advanced workflows. All references match the default layout that appears on first launch.

docs.title: 1. Header Bar
docs.text:
The header spans the top of the window and includes:

  • Application title – Displays the name of the current project and indicates unsaved changes with an asterisk.
  • Navigation tabs – High-level categories (Home, Getting Started, Using The App, etc.) when documentation is loaded within the integrated viewer.
  • Global search – Quickly search commands, panels, signals, or documentation pages.
  • Theme toggle / update alerts – Depending on your build, you may see icons for switching themes or viewing update notifications.

Tip

Use Ctrl/Cmd + P to open the command palette, which searches the same command index as global search.

docs.title: Project Explorer
docs.text:
• Shows the active project, including log files, auxiliary documents, and definitions.
  • Right-click a file to reveal, remove, or open in an external editor.
  • Drag files onto the project explorer to import them quickly.

docs.title: Tools Strip
docs.text:
• Shortcuts to panels such as Signals, Data Injection, Annotations, and Filters.
  • Hover to see tooltips; click to open the associated panel.

docs.title: Definitions
docs.text:
• Lists imported DBC and metadata files.
  • Allows prioritizing definitions when multiple databases define the same signal.

docs.title: 3. Workspace (Center)
docs.text: The workspace hosts dockable panels organized by workflow mode:

docs.title: System Design Mode
docs.text: When working with ECU systems, you'll typically see: - System Canvas – Visual editor for placing ECUs and configuring network connections - Toolbox – Palette of ECU types, networks, and components to add to your system - Properties Panel – Configuration details for selected ECU or network element - Project Explorer – File tree showing system files, configurations, and assets

docs.title: Monitoring Mode
docs.text: When monitoring running ECU containers: - ECU Status Panel – Overview of all running ECUs with state indicators - Console – Aggregated logs from all ECUs with filtering and search - Resource Monitor – Real-time CPU and memory graphs per ECU - Network Traffic – CAN message monitoring and analysis - Terminal – Interactive terminal access to ECU operating systems

docs.title: CAN Log Analysis Mode
docs.text:
When analyzing CAN log files: - Timeline at the top, showing the playhead, selected range, and event markers - Messages panel on the left, presenting raw frames in timestamp order - Charts panel on the right, plotting pinned signals - Signal Viewer – Browse and search decoded signals from DBC files - Signal Player – Playback controls and injection interface

You can rearrange panels by dragging their tabs. Docking cues appear to help position them.

docs.title: 4. Right Sidebar (Inspector)
docs.text:
Displays context-aware details about the selected item, such as:

  • Frame metadata (ID, payload, channel)
  • Signal units and scaling
  • Annotation description and tags
  • Export or injection settings

When nothing is selected, the inspector shows quick links to documentation and keyboard shortcuts.

docs.title: 5. Footer (Status Bar)
docs.text:
Key elements include:

  • Transport controls – Play/Pause, Step Forward/Backward, Jump to Start/End, and Loop toggle.
  • Playback speed selector – Adjust between 0.25× and 8×.
  • Counters – Frames per second, queued exports, injected messages, and time remaining in the selected range.
  • Hardware indicators – Status lights for connected CAN hardware or simulation backends.

docs.title: System Design Panels
docs.text:
• Edit ECU configuration (name, binary path, network interfaces)
  • Configure network parameters (baud rate, channel assignments)
  • Set build targets and compiler options
  • View and modify container runtime settings

docs.title: Project Explorer
docs.text:
• Navigate system files and configurations
  • Browse firmware builds and binaries
  • Manage DBC files and definition libraries
  • Access log files and export artifacts

docs.title: ECU Status Panel
docs.text:
• Grid view of all ECUs with state indicators (running, stopped, error)
  • Quick actions: start, stop, restart, view logs
  • Resource usage summary (CPU%, memory MB)
  • Network connectivity status
  • Double-click to open ECU detail view

docs.title: Console Panel
docs.text:
• Unified log viewer for all ECU outputs
  • Filter by ECU, log level (info, warn, error, debug)
  • Search functionality across log history
  • Color-coded log levels
  • Auto-scroll toggle and pause controls

docs.title: Resource Monitor
docs.text:
• Real-time graphs showing CPU and memory over time
  • Per-ECU metrics with color coding
  • Historical data retention for trend analysis
  • Export metrics as CSV or PNG
  • Alert thresholds for resource exhaustion

docs.title: Network Traffic Panel
docs.text:
• CAN message monitoring with live updates
  • Filter by message ID, channel, or ECU source
  • Message rate statistics and counters
  • Export captured traffic to log files
  • Integration with DBC definitions for signal decoding

docs.title: Terminal Panel
docs.text:
• Multi-tab terminal interface (one per ECU)
  • Full shell access to ECU operating systems
  • Connection status indicators
  • Search functionality (Ctrl+F)
  • Terminal actions: clear, copy, reconnect

docs.title: Process Monitor
docs.text:
• View running processes within ECUs
  • CPU and memory usage per process
  • Process tree visualization
  • Real-time updates

docs.title: Timeline
docs.text:
• Drag to select ranges; double-click to zoom to full duration
  • Right-click to add markers or clear selections
  • Scroll wheel zooms, Shift + scroll pans horizontally

docs.title: Messages Panel
docs.text:
• Filter frames by ID, payload, channel, or time
  • Toggle columns (timestamp, DLC, flags) via the column menu
  • Right-click to export the current filter view

docs.title: Charts Panel
docs.text:
• Supports multiple Y-axes and color-coded signals
  • Add cursors to measure time deltas
  • Save chart screenshots via the context menu

docs.title: Signal Viewer
docs.text:
• Browse decoded signals from DBC definitions
  • Search by signal name, message ID, unit, or tags
  • Pin frequently used signals for quick access
  • View signal metadata and scaling factors

docs.title: Signal Player
docs.text:
• Playback controls for CAN log files
  • Timeline navigation and speed control
  • Injection interface for test message injection
  • Channel selection and filtering

docs.title: Annotations Panel
docs.text:
• Lists bookmarks with timestamps, tags, and descriptions
  • Double-click to jump the timeline to the annotation
  • Export annotations as CSV or include them in reports

docs.title: Data Injection Panel
docs.text:
• Configure message templates, schedules, and profiles
  • Start/stop injections; monitor frame counts and errors
  • Import or export injection profiles for reuse

docs.title: Panel Toggles
docs.text:
• Ctrl/Cmd + 1 – Toggle Signals/ECU Status panel (context-dependent)
  • Ctrl/Cmd + 2 – Toggle Messages/Console panel
  • Ctrl/Cmd + 3 – Toggle Charts/Resource Monitor panel
  • Ctrl/Cmd + 4 – Toggle Data Injection/Terminal panel
  • Ctrl/Cmd + W – Close the active panel tab
  • Alt + Arrow keys – Switch between docked panel tabs

docs.title: System Design
docs.text:
• Ctrl/Cmd + N – Create new system
  • Ctrl/Cmd + O – Open system
  • Ctrl/Cmd + S – Save system
  • Delete – Remove selected ECU or network element (when canvas focused)

docs.title: CAN Playback
docs.text:
• Space – Play/Pause playback
  • Arrow Left/Right – Step backward/forward
  • Home/End – Jump to start/end of log
  • Shift + C – Add cursor to chart

docs.title: 8. Customizing the UI
docs.text:
• Drag panel edges to resize.
  • Use View → Reset Layout to recover from accidental rearrangements.
  • Save layout variants inside a project for quick context switching (e.g., Analysis vs. Injection layout).
  • Access Settings → Theme to choose dark/light or Catppuccin-inspired color schemes if available.

docs.title: 9. Embedded Documentation Viewer
docs.text: If the documentation is packaged with the app, selecting Help → User Guide opens this site within an embedded view, allowing cross-referencing while you work. The viewer retains navigation history and respects the same theme colors as the main app.

docs.title: 10. Where to Go Next
docs.text:
• Configure layouts in Workspaces & Layouts.
  • Learn how each panel supports your tasks in Controls & Panels.
  • When you are comfortable with navigation, proceed to Playback and Filters & Search to master data analysis.

docs.title: Workspaces & Layouts
docs.text: Workspaces control the arrangement of panels inside TrueFidelity. Mastering layouts allows you to switch rapidly between analysis, injection, and reporting tasks without rebuilding the UI each time.

docs.title: Layout Basics
docs.text:
• Default layout: Timeline top, Messages left, Charts right, Signals panel collapsed on the left, Annotations tabbed with Messages.
  • Docking: Drag panel tabs to docking zones (edges of the workspace) to snap panels to new positions. Blue highlights show the docking target.
  • Floating panels: Drag a tab outside the main window to float it. Useful on multi-monitor setups.
  • Stacking: Drop panels on top of each other to create tabbed groups.
  • Resizing: Drag dividers to allocate more space to a panel. Hold Shift for finer adjustments.

docs.title: Saving and Loading Layouts
docs.text:
1. Arrange panels the way you like.
  2. Go to View → Save Layout (or use the layout dropdown in the toolbar).
  3. Name the layout (e.g., Analysis, Injection, Review).
  4. Layouts are stored per project; export them if you want to share with teammates.

To switch layouts, choose from the layout dropdown or View → Load Layout. Layout changes persist between sessions once saved.

docs.title: Analysis Layout
docs.text:
• Timeline full width at top.
  • Messages left, Charts right, Signals pinned below Messages.
  • Annotations docked at the bottom for quick tagging.
  • Watch list visible for rapid chart updates.

docs.title: Injection Layout
docs.text:
• Data Injection panel docked left.
  • Messages centered to monitor the effect.
  • Charts right with key metrics pinned.
  • Timeline narrower—focus on real-time injection counters.

docs.title: Review Layout
docs.text:
• Timeline top with wide selection area.
  • Charts occupying most of the workspace for visual storytelling.
  • Annotations and Reports panels docked right.
  • Messages minimized; open only when needing raw payloads.

Tip

Create a dedicated layout for exporting reports. Include the Annotation panel, Report Builder, and a Notes panel to capture narratives.

docs.title: Layout Shortcuts
docs.text:
• Ctrl/Cmd + Shift + L: Open layout switcher (if enabled in your build).
  • Ctrl/Cmd + Shift + 1/2/3: Apply saved layouts directly (assign shortcuts under Settings → Shortcuts).

docs.title: Using Multiple Monitors
docs.text:
• Float Charts and place them on a secondary monitor for full-screen visualization.
  • Keep Messages and Signals on the primary monitor alongside the timeline to maintain context.
  • Save a DualDisplay layout to restore positions after reconnecting monitors.

docs.title: Sharing Layouts
docs.text:
1. Open View → Manage Layouts.
  2. Select a layout and click Export to save a .tflayout file.
  3. Share the file with a teammate; they can import it via View → Import Layout.
  4. After import, the layout appears in their layout list for the current project.

docs.title: Resetting Layouts
docs.text:
• Choose View → Reset Layout to revert to factory defaults.
  • Resetting does not remove saved layouts; you can reapply them afterwards.
  • If a floating panel disappears off-screen, reset to bring it back.

docs.title: Layouts and Projects
docs.text:
• Layouts are stored within the project configuration. Opening the project on another machine preserves your layout preferences.
  • Changing the default layout in Settings → Workspace updates the layout applied when you create new projects.
  • Use project templates (pre-configured .tfproj files) to distribute common layouts and default filters.

docs.title: Advanced Tips
docs.text:
• Pair layouts with keyboard shortcuts to match your workflow. Example: assign Alt + 1 to Analysis, Alt + 2 to Injection.
  • Combine layout changes with panel-specific presets. For instance, save a chart view with specific signals and enable it only in the Review layout.
  • Use different color themes per layout. Some teams prefer bright themes for daytime analysis and dark Catppuccin for overnight monitoring.

docs.title: Troubleshooting Layout Problems
docs.text: Problem Solution Panel stuck in floating mode Reset layout, then reapply saved layout. If using multiple monitors, ensure they are detected by the OS. Layouts missing after upgrade Layouts are stored per project. Reopen the original project or import exported .tflayout backups. Panels overlap after resolution change Reset layout or load a layout designed for the new resolution. Layout dropdown empty You may have created the layout in another project. Export from that project and import into the current one.

docs.text:

  • Visit Controls & Panels for panel-specific configuration tips.
